content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have been playing this game pre-EA release, and I can honestly say it is one of the most enjoyable casual games I have ever played. It has a perfect balance between city building, RPG elements and crafting, and gives you a rewarding feeling of progression. Each citizen has their own stats and skills that can be improved and you get a real sense of a village community developing. I'll just summerise the rest into simple pros and cons:PRO- Fantastic mix of city-building/RPG- Simple yet very pretty graphics- frequent updates and very good developer communication- A slow yet steady rate of progressionCON- villager professions not yet finished so feel abit lacking in variety- a few bugs here and there- can be hard at times as death of a skilled citizen can set you back for a whileI would strongly recommend giving this game a go and looking at the future plans for this game on the developers website, exciting things planned!

content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								To me, the 25$ was a bit steep for something that you could technically "accomplish" within 2 hours. I mean if you're into expanding and creating towns and furnishing the houses with the prettiest of flowers, you'll love it, but if you're like me with just striving to hit the top of the research chain/skill tree, it's a bit easy. I'd say you could compare this a little bit to Banished in some several yet different ways.Pros:-Easy to learn-Visually nice-Can design your own buildings-Nice mix of city builder/management-Some slightly unique concepts-Is playable in it's current state-Slow progression, but actually being updatedCons:-Bugs, lots of 'em.-Crashing is frequent (Until you update your drivers)-Occasionally slightly broken UI (F5 to fix)-Not fully complete job tree (yet)-Weird inventory viewing systemAll in all, I would reccomend this game. I did find it enjoyable for the 2 hours I played, but until more is added, I'll just wait patiently. Maybe a price drop would be nice as well.

Early Access Review
								A note on the negative comments: I've read through the negs on the reviews and in 99% of cases, the problem is easily resolved if you check the forums on the stonehearth webpage. Usually the problems are solved with a reboot of the game due to errors while the game engine is still in developement. I have almost 900 hours on this game. content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have played Stonehearth for 341 hours and have enjoyed playing through the developing stages. The game is becoming more polished and seems to be headed in a positive direction. I would recommend this to someone who enjoys a sandbox building and crafting games where they can design towns and villages with a little bit of hostile goblins thrown in to the mix.I do not recommend this yet for someone that is expecting a finished polished product or get upset when an error message pops up.The Good- I find the game extremely fun to play with the ability to design your own houses and structures.  - The pace of the game is relaxing and the music is very soothing. - The Heathing are amusing as they try to carry out your commands- There are more creatures to worry about now as Giant Zombie, Stone Golems, Eants, and what looks like a mutant alligator roam the land. Undead Villages complete with crazed necromancers pop up and flood the night with undead critters.- The ability to create Mods will mean continued content. I hope that this also continues to develop end game content.- Weekly twitch feed keep you updated on developments and lets you give feed back to the developers.The Bad- There are still errors when trying to build structures, and it takes a while to learn what works and what does not. It seems the building logic really wants you to lay down your design in a certain way. I watched a twitch feed were the designer was working on this to allow the engine to be more flexible.- The Hearthling become idler as your town, village, Kingdom expands. I am unsure if this is caused by distance, memory issues or pathing (although sometime it’s because I ran out of wood). The developers have work hard and these issues have improved greatly since I started playing it. (I still have to chop my own wood of course)- The end game is not there yet.  There is a basic scenario evolving Blood thirsty goblins which ends after 4 or 5 encounters.  Following that you only have to fend off random creatures once or twice a day.    I will continue to play and follow this game as it develops.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								In its current state, I have to recommend this game!Couple of points at the end explain the overall rating.Pros: - Cute Artstyle - AI 90% of the time is perfect - Can build almost anything you want to - Hard mode actually adds survival challenge to this otherwise peaceful town builder - Constantly being developed/improved - Indepth profession system with RPG style progression - Happy to just watch my villagers do their thing!Cons: - AI doesn't work 10% of the time - Buildings you designate to build sometime never get finished (Look at bottom of post) - Combat AI is dodgey. I have to tell them to Defend a location, to get them to attack monstersNotes:The reason it is a yes is solely based upon the ability to use the Command Console (CTRL + SHIFT + C).This allows you to Instantly Build buildings your villagers refuse to build, and you can destroy buildings already created.Without these two commands (IB & Destroy), I would have raged quit this game years ago.I'd say 50% of custom buildings never get finished if they are semi-complicated. Sometimes the villagers, when you tell them to place items, never actually place it and you're stuck with the ghost icon.But with 'Destroy', you get rid of it, and with 'IB' you can sort the building issues out!You even have a Teleport command if your villagers get stuck!Hopefully they will remove the need for the console, but until then I have to give this a 8/10 IF you use the Console.Without the Console, it'd only be a 5/10.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is my very first review for any game, I just feel compelled to do it! My first impression of Stonehearth after watching their video wasn't good. This is my very first uh I don't know what to call it, 2D-pixel voxel game? Anyway, I was a bit turned off by it. I've always avoided minecraft for that reason. Also, the price of $24.99 for this type of game seemed a bit too much for me. Anyway, I spent a couple of weeks thinking about it, watched their intro video at least 4 times and finally caved and bought the game the other night. Stonehearth has been such a delight to play. I thoroughly enjoy the job/class and advancement systems. I love the cuteness that is the game, even the boxy critters and animals are adorable. Building your own homes can be quite a challenge, which adds to the fun for me. I also love being able to use a building template the game provides and customize it to my own preference if I'm too lazy to create my own. I love renaming my citizens! I love that I can assign them to their own beds! I love that the cook helps my farmer harvest the fields :D As you can see, I enjoy a lot of the little features in Stonehearth which is why I felt compelled to make this review and share my experience with others. If you enjoy survival/strategy city-builders with cute pets and citizens + job/class advancements, then I highly suggest this game to you. Imo, this is one of those games that's worth the price tag. I love what the developers have done with the game so far and I'm happy to support this early access title.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Dude. DUDE. Look at this.It's an Early Access game... and they're WORKING ON IT.I've been playing Stonehearth on and off for a while, the interest spikes obviously coinciding with updates, and I am glad to say this game does not have potential. It has promise. Because a promise is something you actually follow through on.Like everyone else is saying, it is by no means complete. Think about it: it's a sandbox game and they only just put the zombies and water in. How complete is that to you?But it all works, more or less. More THAN less. There are peculiarities, certainly - when I tell you tiny voxel people to pick berries, I mean I want you to TAKE those berries back to town - but it doesn't hiccup too often. And there have been some interesting hiccups. The biggest one, which involved two separate timers ingame and their misbehavior, the devs actually detailed in a blog post.Which brings me to the dev team, Radiant. These people talk with their community, and their community talks back. And they communicate often. Weekly - or so,♥♥♥♥♥♥happens - posts keep everyone appraised of what's going on with/in to the game, which is always nice to see. And I've seen some♥♥♥♥♥♥ man... I purchased Cube World.Now, I want to draw attention to something that I think is important. Stonehearth is currently in Alpha 10 - every time there's a large content update, they bump that number up by one. And it's only just now on Early Access, despite it going up on Steam early so Kickstarter patrons would have an easier time of it.That means they waited until they had a significant amount of content in the game before going Early Access.Seriously, Radiant. Y'all're beautiful.If you like boxy sandboxes and RTS-type games, give this one a whirl. I think you'll like it.

number of helpful: 168 of 203 people (83%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
Early Access Review
Welcome, to the Hearth!Heya guys, and gals, and welcome to my little review on Stonehearth, a lovable Early-Access title brought to you from the developers at Radient Entertainment, an indie-game studio based in Los Altos, California.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Initially when I first stumbled upon Stonehearth, it was after the dark ages seen from similar titles, notebly the game Castle Story from Sauropod Studios. An early access game as well, and with a similar feel initially, the game suffered quickly due to lack of development and the $30.00 price tag on a -usually- broken and unsatisfying experience. Coming to Stonehearth, I was a bit relictant to try a new title under the Early Access title and with the same feel.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------So let's get into it, what is Stonehearth all about?Stonehearth is a meshed combination of a City Builder but with a mix of RPG and Adventure elements. Your journey begins as one of the two (current) races available to play (four are planned so far in total). Starting out, you and your handful of citizens (Hearthlings) are tasked with constructing your very own "city on a hill", a home in the wilderness of one of two (current) biomes.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The Races and FactionsThere, at this time, is only a single race playable in the game which of course, are the humans. However, the humans are split into two factions (currently) with a third planned in the future. The human factions that are known about now are:The AscendencyOriginally posted by Stonehearth Official Wiki: "Earnest and hardworking, loyal and well-rounded. Citizens of the Ascendency chop, build, and farm, confident that the known world is theirs to inhabit."The Ascendency are the basic human faction, based off of Eastern European countries they are home to the temperate biome and start their crafting tree around the Carpenter, a specialist who uses wood resources to create works from tools and weapons, to building components and decorations. They don't do well in the desert however, due to their heavy dependance on wood resources.Raya's ChildrenOriginally posted by Stonehearth Official Wiki: "The scattered people of the mountains learned early that to survive, they needed each other - and preferable as many others as they could reach. Now, though the members of their trading cities and traveling caravans pride themselves on ascetic disciplin, visitors find them generous hosts with access to goods from all over the world."The second released human faction, named the Raya's Children, are designed from a more Middle Eastern resemblance. Living a life in the vast deserts in the world, they have learned to cope with the lack of wood and traditional building materials found elsewhere. Instead of a Carpenter, they begin with a Potter, an artisan skilled in crafting bricks of clay and stone to form efficient housing solutions.Th Northmen's Alliance (NOT RELEASED)Originally posted by Stonehearth Official Wiki: "Brave and handy, the men and women of the north live for the sight of a new dawn over unexplored territory. Armed with compass and hatchet, they form strings of small, defensible settlements and pride themselves in their tenacious adaptability."The third faction planned for the human race are the Northmen's Alliance. Based on the Vikings from northern Europe and the surrounding tundras, they are a hardworking collection of natural-born explorers and fighters. They are home to the tundra biome, and additional details for them have yet to be released.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------GameplayThe game begins with the main menu, as every game should. Upon stating up a new game you are presented with the choices you shall make, the biome you choose to inhabit, people you choose to play as, and the difficulty to which you would like to play as. It is a simple process, freshened up from a traditional selection screen by being presented to you in the form of a story book, with the choices you make appearing to fill the blanks of the story.Once past, you are sent into the Expedition Roster, a list of several Hearthlings which you will start with. Each Hearthling comes with a randomly rolled attribute set spread across three categories.Mind - Useful for those who will become your fine artisans and crafters, Mind stats help these Hearthlings advance in their career as well as gives a boost to their ability to craft Fine items, creations which are adorned with supreme craftsmanship.Body - Granting bonus stats to boost Hearthling health and movement speed, a high Body stat is excellent for Footmen and combat specialists, but also those who will greatly benefit from the passive speed boost, ie. Farmers and Trappers.Spirit - A key for those going into combat, Spirit attribute points grant a boost to Hearthling courage and morale. High Spirited combat specialists will stand firm in combat, even after sustaining injuries.If you happen to have unfavorable traits, you can try again for as many times as you like with the 'Roll new citizens' button, regenerating all seven Hearthlings. Once finished, on the right side you are greeted by a list of various items for purchase, and a small budget of initial gold for you to purchase things or take along with you on your journey.With your citizens ready to depart and your expedition supplies tied down and stowed for your adventure, it finally comes time to select your site to begin! With reach game of Stonehearth, the maps are randomly generated using seeds, viewable at the bottom of the screen. You can reroll maps for as many times as you wish, alike the Expedtion Roster. To note with your location as you move your cursor over the map, the highlighted box around your cursor represents the actual in-game map, which although seems small compared to the world map, offers plenty of space for your city's development and then some. On the right side, you will also see three major variables which change on the area you select.Trees and Plants - This is pretty self-explanetory on the fact that this value shows how many plants and trees are located in the settlement region you have highlighted.Wildlife - This factor represents the amount of creatures found in the highlighted region, useful for your trappers who will need animals in order to efficiently trap and harvest them.Minerals - This final factor represents the amount of ores, stone deposits, and the etc. which are readily located in the highlighted region. You can always however, mine for ore in a region with little to no Mineral rating, it just takes some time.Once you have your region selected and good to go, you can embark on your journey!-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The Review PartA simple, yet equally complex game, Stonehearth is a game easily loveable by Adventure, RPG, City-builder, and Strategy fans. Built in a voxel art style with a friendly and cute feel to it, it is aesthetically pleasing and especially for those who run the game on higher graphics settings. Keep in mind that there are faults of course, various quirks and bugs are present as you can expect with an Early-Access title, however the weekly Development Team reports and progressing updates are great! There are currently a collection of simple quests and side-missions to keep you interested along with a developing story in the works. Overall I again, highly recommend this title, and encourage you to try it out!Thanks for reading, happy building!- Kyoko

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a great game. It's a merge of Dwarf Fortress and Minecraft; The former for it's 'base-building' and management aspects, the latter for it's voxel graphics. TL;DR Pros/Cons list: + Good replay value + Looks great + Large amount of craftable items and professions + Building Designer + Villagers level up and unlock skills + Frequently updated - Rather buggy, villagers tend to get confused very often and so on - Combat is slow and iffy at times - Game will often break if you don't save often to avoid doing things that break it - Some 'texture' issues - Few pre-built structures - Lack of game customisation (monster spawn rates, villagers, etc)In Stonehearth, your goal (if any) is rather simple: to build a thriving medieval village/city, and take care of the various needs of your villagers (known has hearthlings) along the way.You don't have direct control over your villagers like an RTS; you give them orders to perform and they'll find a way to do it (most of the time) themselves.As you progress in-game, and your villagers level up, you'll slowly unlock more proffessions for them to practice, and thus more furniture, decoration, tools and weapons for them to use.You will not, however, unlock new buildings, as the game only has 5 (I believe) pre-built ones. The rest is up to you to build, using the game's Building Designer feature, which works more or less the same as 'The Sims' Build Mode, with a tab bit less freedom.Hearthlings tend to have issues when building; I have had to help them off of roofs, demolish a building because they couldn't build scaffolding or because they just go on strike and won't build anything at all.Be sure to leave at least a block of space around a building when planning it out; your hearthlings won't be able to build the scaffolding if not.Decoration-wise, there are tons to choose from, ranging from beds, to flower pots or braziers. Each crafting profession has some form of decoration. My villages have gotten prettier and prettier over time as I've discovered new crafts.The game's replay value is rather high, as attempting to create a functional village in different environments can be a challenge at times (on top of a mountain, for example ^^).The game is also rather buggy in it's current state; several times I have had to start a new game because I placed a path over another and the villagers refused to build anything else, or because I was planning a custom building and none of my orders would work anymore.Many blocks/items sometimes overlay eachother as well, causing flickering textures which can get rather irritating at times.I've also had issues where my one fighter hearthling has gotten themselves stuck in an infinite loop of 'Attack Golbing Chieftan > Run away from Goblin Chieftan'. Seeing as there is no direct control over the villagers, I can't do anything to get them to stop, and just have to wait for something to hopefully kill them.All in all, Stonehearth is a great game to own if you're into the genre and I highly recommend it.The frequent updates make it a great game to come back to from time to time.If I were to rate it out of 10 like everyone else seems to, I'd have to give it the following: 7/10.For an Early Acces game, it has a good amount of content, looks good, is fun to play, but the bugs it has in it's current state sometimes ruin the experience.

Posted: December 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have followed and been trying this game out since the beginning. I first got hooked when it was a concept from someone that seemed to have a passion for what he wanted to do and what he wanted to make.This game is the type of early Access that steam needs. More developers should actually follow this style. Here we have a guy that had his game available while in developement with it hardly being playable. We had the chance to see the game receive slow but steady streams of content flowing in and bug squashing. I used to not be able to get 5 minutes before everyone decided they wanted to sit around and do nothing. But unlike other developers, This guy actually kept at it. and unlike other developers. When the cash flowed in... they slowed down, He sped up. The closest relation i can give this developer style is like Dwarf Fortress. Not in terms of gameplay, but how he steadily adds content while fixing issues with the game. and any dwarf loving fan will know that it takes a while for each of the updates to come out.TL:DR - Developer set realistic goals to meet with limited resources. And keeps meeting them.

Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Well, it's finally here... Steam Early Access! I couldn't be happier for Team Radiant! :)Disclaimer: I am an official fanboy, and hold this development studio in the highest esteem. But in my defense, I think this is perfectly justified given how open and transparent this team is with their fans and supporters.All that aside, what do I actually think about Stonehearth? I think it has the potential to be one of the most entertaining games we've seen in these combined genres in ages. There's a wealth of things that the team has already implemented (building!, classes, crafting, mining, combat) and a whole host of others in the works.With each new update the team trickles out improvements to the game's foundation (better performance, more stability) and introduces new mechanics and content as well for the community to test drive. You will be hard pressed to find another team that is as open with their backers as these folks, and its always rewarding to see topics discussed with the team in their bi-weekly stream actually implemented in the game.I think I'll leave this review for now, and revisit as each new major release is dropped (roughly every month to month and a half). If you are at all interested in the title, I highly encourage to drop by the Discourse and mingle with some other fans and backers. Watch a few LP series and see just what Stonehearth has to offer at this stage of development.I have a feeling you'll be glad you did! :)p.s. if you are interested in watching a town be rebuilt ... *several* times, look no further! :p

Posted: September 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's an ant farm that you control. Virtual Villagers but infinitely better. Simply the best town sim I've played.Pros- Combat is fun to watch.- Art direction is beautiful.- You can design the buildings.- Skill/design curve is huge so it's always interesting to do something new.- Actually, everything is fun to watch.Cons- Sometimes workers task weird.- Very CPU(?) intensive. - A strong push by goblin armies can wipe you if you're new.- Haven't seen any water yet. Would like water.- Engineer takes way too much to level. Mason -> Blacksmith -> Engineer, way too much of an EXP grind.Protips- Build a wall early on- Always have a standing army.- I figured out the holy trinity of MMORPGS work with 1 knight, 3 footmen, and 1 cleric. I was able to take on anything with this.- Design your own buildings! Increase efficiency by putting ten beds in one house! Your Hearthlings will love you! ( Love not guaranteed. )- When starting, most people overdo the farm plots. Anything over 15x15 would be overkill until later on.- Use the 'maintain' option if you're building multiple buildings.- You can build walls via pasture enclosements or design building.Suggestions- Let us place objects from storage units into the world. I can't access my piles of stone / clay.- Make the market stalls have different merchants.Overall : 9.5/10. A little buggy, but one of the best games that you could buy for 25$. I'd value it at 35$ at most. Make sure you don't run this on an old computer or you could start freezing or crashing. I've had no problems with the game, great direction.SpecsWin 1016 GB DDR4 RAMIntel i5 6600Radeon RX 480

Posted: June 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have been following the game since the kickstarter and it has gone from strength to strength. After a long process of developing the core systems and streamlining the game engine the game has come on quite rapidly. Appreciate at this stage that the game IS an alpha but also know that new content is being made rapidly at this stage. They have a team of full time staff working hard away 5 days a week to make sure this game reaches its fans so dont think that buying at this stage is a "gamble". You WILL get the finished product. The game its self is soo fun to play. A perfect blend of city management with sim life without a crazy amount of micro-management. The game also features very easy mod integration and is built using easy to understand languages. The team have published full documentation on getting started on modding too so if you want to get started, you can do so at any time. It's my recommendation that you buy this game now and try it for yourself. At this stage you will get a good feeling for the final product. For the price you will rarley find something that you will get the same amount of gameplay out of.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								Before I begin, let me say this:  I understand Stonehearth is in Early Access.  I don't expect everything to work flawlessly. That having been said, the game needs a lot of work.I picked up Stonehearth based on a lot of Steam user reviews comparing it to Dwarf Fortress.  I like Dwarf Fortress, even though the game is notorious for its extremely obfuscated interface.  Stonehearth sacrifices a lot of DF's detailed simulation for a more accessible experience, which is fine with me.  However, as of March 2016, the current build is badly broken.  A few of the weird AI glitches I've seen include Hearthlings that join the settlement, but idle in one place permanently.  After accepting a new Hearthling (hereafter referred to as "plebs"), I watched her stand on a hill for a week, regardless of any orders I issued.  She was eventually eaten by wolves.  Footmen, Stonehearth's 'soldier' class, will charge after enemies they have no chance of defeating, regardless of their current orders.  When they're reduced to 1/4 health, they flee for a few moments, then turn back and resume fighting.  I've lost at least four Footmen because of this behavior.  Mobs also have a tendency to spawn in weird locations, like at the end of a long tunnel with only one entrance.  I got a notification informing me that one of my plebs was mauled to death by wolves, at the end of a mining tunnel with a closed door at the entrance.  Either something's up with the spawning algorithm, or all dogs don't go to heaven.  I'm saying they're ghost dogs.  Way of the samurai.The building system is suprisingly robust.  The interface makes it easy to plot foundations, walls, upper floors, and roofs.  I actually designed some pretty handsome structures, and the process was fairly intuitive and straightforward.  However, once I actually placed my blueprint and ordered my plebs to build the structure, I ran into more AI issues.  On two separate occasions, my plebs stopped building before the structure was complete.  They'd build to around 3/4 completion, then idle, as though they had nothing to do.  Reloading the game did nothing.  Suspending all jobs, then re-assigning them did nothing.  I simply had a partially-finished shell of a building in the middle of my settlement.  I tried to remove it, but my plebs demolished about half of the building, then idled again.  My town looks like Detroit in 1996.  Shameful display.Despite all the AI issues, I still like the game.  The art style is charming, and the UI makes it easy to place buildings and command your plebs.  Once they iron out the issues with plebs abandoning construction halfway through, I think it's going to be a joy to play.  The interface handles walls and roofs very gracefully, and building blueprints for structures is a breeze.  I remember placing roofs in "Towns," a similar town-building game, was a living nightmare.  Most importantly, while scanning the forums for solutions to my AI issues, I saw that the devs were very active, involved with, and respectful to their players.  That's a very good sign.  For the time being, I'm going to recommend this game.  I was excited enough about the premise that I didn't mind the $25 price tag, but if cost is an issue for you, I'd recommend holding off until they get a beta build up and running.  Bottom line:  despite some pretty rampant AI issues, the game shows a lot of promise.  As long as the devs stay active and listen to their player base, I think this is going to mature into a very enjoyable experience.[UPDATE 3/13/16]  All of my footmen got thwomped by a one-two combo of ghost dogs and giant zombies, so I decided to start a new settlement in sandbox mode.  So far, I've experienced none of the AI glitches I saw in 'normal' mode.  It seems that something about combat, or placing my settlement on defense mode, breaks the AI.  I'm hoping the devs fix this, because I enjoyed the challenge of defending against sporadic attacks from invaders and thieves.  For the time being, however, I'd recommend you play in sandbox mode.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								In StoneHearth, you begin the game on a randomly generated map similar to a Minecraft map. The gameplay is similar to a strategy game, as you do not control directly any character. You just give orders and expect them to be followed. You start with 7 Settlers, each having their own sets of strenghts & weaknesses. One may be thriving in handcrafting while another is suited for military missions. With these settlers, you'll build and develop a camp thanks to all the resources available. These resources are various, and it can be compared here with Terraria for instance.To grow, you'll focus on developing the skills of your settlers, assigning them jobs, and gathering as much resources as possible. But these objectives can be endangered by the presence of enemies at night: zombies, skeletons, goblins. You'll have to manage a small military force to protect yourself.The final objective of the game in its current state is more or less to build your 'perfect base', and survive long enough to do so.Similar games:- Stronghold- The SettlersCool features:- Daily events and Trade, to earn gold and buy resources you lack of- The Building design system, which is quite good and allow you to design your dream city/base- Progression system for settlersIn its current state, the game is good, and the potential is interesting. I recommand it if you enjoy this kind of game (Check the Settlers especially).

number of helpful: 58 of 67 people (87%) found this review helpful24 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
Early Access Review
As Daft Punk once said, "buy it, use it, break it, fix it, trash it, change it, mail - upgrade it".Or at least, something like that. You get my point.So, Stonehearth (gosh, that's one unfortunate title *cough*Hearthstone*cough*) is a very promising *deep breath* early access city building, minecraftesque, RPG, strategy, survival, crafting game. Whew, that was long.You start by choosing the background of your hearthlings, their place to settle and the difficulty. Then, you take the role of the taskmaster as you have to guide your people. Craft, build, assign jobs, harvest, defend against hunger, goblins, golems etc. NOTE: As nightfalls come and go, be advised that mobs will become slowly, but surely, more difficult to face. The gameplay is all about choosing the best decision about your everyday actions and proper resource management (whether that's your hearthlings or your food). You have to direct your workers to crafting or collecting what you think you need mostly and prepare for the dangers that descend upon you every night. But what if you make the wrong choice? You don't have to worry about that, since the game has a perfect pace to give you the time to think carefully about your choices and correct those that turned up to be a disaster. One very unique aspect, which I enjoyed very much (I got up from my chair and clapped my hands when I saw it), is the ability to design unique houses for your hearthlings. True, you got the default building templates, but you can also choose the size, materials, style, decoration of each construction you plan to make and model it to your heart's desire. Kudos for that, it was an excellent idea from the developers and I don't think any other city building game has ever done that.On the downside, the game is still in Alpha. Be prepared for game-breaking bugs and it's a good idea to report them in order to help the devs improve the game as fast as possible.The hearthlings' AI is a bit clumsy at times too, so don't be surprised if your people simply ignore the goblins stealing their precious resources or taking years to clear a specific side of the forest you ordered them to cut down. Hopefully, it will be improved in future patches and builds.Personal suggestions towards the developers: I look forward to the addition of multiplayer, new biomes, new nations and better AI.Overall, if you are into this genre, give it a shot when you can afford it and you won't regret it. *wink*RATING:Gameplay: 7.5/10 (due to several bugs that can create a big mess)Presentation: 8/10Story: 8.5/10Unique Factor: Entertainment: 8.5/10OVERALL: 8.1/10

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been following this game for a long time, I actually missed the kickstarter by a few days.. and it is unfortunate because I really wanted to support them in a bigger way. This game means quite a bit to me it really got me back into gaming which I was very apathetic about all newer game titles. I've been in the testing phases of this game for a long time pretty much as soon as they allowed you to buy in from their website and I honestly have never regretted it. The game itself is quirky. There is a lot of stuff going on and bugs happen, but I can absolutely assure anyone who is put off by this that it will be fixed. In the older builds there were major funny, and breaking bugs.. which messed up the gameplay but the devise are always diligent to squash anything they can as promptly as possible. I can't recommend this game enough simply because it has such an amazing community. It already has modders, the devs are very active and as transparent as possible, biweekly dev streams where people in chat can actually influence the shape of the game, devs are very appreciative of their community and open to suggestions, and much more. The team definitely has a vision of where this game is going, and they are honestly working their asses off to achieve it.. And so far they are hitting the nail on the head every time. Their over all may not be exactly what I was wanting... But the modding scene well have us covered on that front. New builds come out every few weeks.. Sometimes they are buggy sometimes they are not. It all depends on what what changed or how much new content is thrown it. Fixes usually come within a few days but sometimes require a larger update to fix. I pretty much play this game for 5 or 10 hours every other weekend testing the new content, trying out new ideas, etc.. The content is steadily growing at decent rate. Overall for me this game scratches an itch I've had since finally abandoning dwarf fortress. I look forward to participating in this community for years to come.

number of helpful: 69 of 85 people (81%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								When I took a screenshot of Stonehearth, and shared it with my friend, the first thing he asked was "Is that a Minecraft clone?" Seriously, no. If you think a complex city building and management game is a clone of Minecraft, you need to really get a reality check, bud. Anyway, moving on to the actual review. First, you should know that I've been playing Stonehearth since the pre-alpha days, and that this review is for Alpha 10.5. I'm also basing this only on the content that is currently available, and not promised stuff due out later in development. Though, I'm personally looking forward to PvP combat, which is going to be a feature later on. SOUNDSound design is average, and everything you'd expect to be there, is there. You've got grunts, a catchy (if not a tad repetitive) soundtrack, and all the other standard musical cues you'd expect from a video game. -7/10GAMEPLAYYou've got the foundations of a pretty awesome city building game, though there's a clear lack of content as of this writing. The core city building aspect is most definitely there, and you're able to build custom structures, mine for resources, and even fight invading monsters. I've yet to actually figure out what happens if you lose all of your guys to a city invasion, and the enemies don't seem to do much other than invade, and rush you with numbers. But at the very least, it's the start of something major. You're also able to create squads to better fend off enemy invasion, and the city building animations are fascinating. I found myself building random structures just to see how my little minions (yes, that's what I call them) would construct it. -9/10FEATURESUnfortunately, the game is currently lacking in the feature department. While the actual gameplay is polished beyond what you'd expect for an Early Access game, it isn't without its faults. For starters, there is very little in the way of configuration. There's no graphic slider, or volume control. This is really just a core experience right now, and you know what? I'm oddly okay with that. This is just an alpha after all. Things will improve. -8/10CONCLUSION All in all, Stonehearth offers a very solid city building experience. Considering as how this is only just in alpha, Stonehearth feels like a finished product. It has polish, it has style. It's just an all around fun experience. Sure, there's a fair number of bugs, though none of them are game breaking, at least in my testing. This is an alpha, so a bug or two is expected. But the fact that Stonehearth plays and feels like a finished product? Well, that's just darn amazing. So yes, I recommend Stonehearth. Final rating? 8.5/10. (note: this review was for alpha version 10.5)

number of helpful: 47 of 52 people (90%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have played this game off and on for about 6 months and can honestly recommend the game. It is still in development, but the developers are extremely engaged and regularly release updates with bug fixes, new content, etc. The core of the game is solid and offers significant room for customization of the buildings within your town. At present, there are bugs, but this is expected. What is promising is that many of the bugs I have observed over the course of the past 6 months, have been taken care of. Do new bugs pop up when new content is released? Of course. However, they are typically resolved within a month, at most, of the new content's release.The game itself is primarily a city builder with random raids of goblins, undead, etc thrown in to keep the game play interesting and varied. The combat system is a bit wonky at present, but has been steadily improving over time which is a good indication of future improvements to come.Resource gathering has become rather staightforward and it is relatively easy to keep your villagers gathering what you want them to. It does require a bit of micromanagement as there is not a way to automate their gathering behavior at present (e.g. mine when copper is below 20 in storage, gather wood when inventory is below 15, etc). Once the resources are gathered, though, the tradesmen can be completely automated to maintain inventory levels of the items you wish to produce (e.g. set the Blacksmith to maintain 5 swords in inventory, etc)In sum, despite the bugs that I have experienced and room for future improvement, I would highly recommend this game. It has vast potential, a very active development team that is engaged with the community, and is generally enjoyable to play.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been following this game since it's Kickstarter days and am very pleased with the progress it has made thusfar. Stonehearth is a sandboxish city builder, simulation game with added rpg like elements. Whether you just want to build your dream village, fight off incoming invaders, or dig the deepest mine, this game has it all. Designing buildings has never been easier and allows for many possibilties and custimizations and your hearthlings will automatically build what you design for them. The profession system gives you various choices to decide which directions you want your little town.Radiant Entertainment are some of the most community driven developers I have ever come across. They are constantly livestreaming the game development and intereacting with the community on the forums. As this game  has a tendency of having some (often hilarious) bugs here and there as any Alpha game does, the team is very quick at releasing patch versions to adress these kind of errors.Modding is another core component in this game. Being new to moding myself, it is amazing to see how easy it is to mod the game, even in this early state, and should get much easier as the game develops. There is already a nice variety of community made mods available on the stonehearth forums.All in all I definitly recomend this to anyone who loves city builders, rpgs and sandbox games.  If you are a hardcore Dwarf Fortress gamer, I suggest you give Stonehearth a try. With the progress Radiant has made so far, I am definitly excited to see what they have in store for multiplayer and the other features they want to add to this wonderful game!~Avairian

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Early Access Review: (Review might change over updates so be wary)When I first saw this game it's concepts and looks instantly reminded me of the game called Trove (no advertisment induced). The charming graphics and animations alone make this game so good but the real deal comes with building.The start:- You start the game by picking 2 races: The Raya and the Ascendancy. Both races differ a lot.- The Ascendancy starts off with the initial job Carpenter: The man who does miracles with wood. They are also the better farmers to play with.- The Raya start with the initial job potter: the mastermind of clay. But here's the catch. The carpenter can craft the wooden sword right away to promote a settler to a footman so you can fend off enemies early on while the potter cannot. So starting with the raya first is harder for newbies.After you picked your race you have to set the biome. There's one homeland for each race. Choosing the opposite homeland makes no real difference whatsoever. Both have wood and stone to start with. Only the wood/stone/clay ratio is different. Note that you can farm on both grassland and plains.After choosing the biome you get the chance to edit your starting people. You can rename them and reroll the entirety for random stats. Also you can but some starting items from you 150g pool.At the end but not least you only have to set your difficulty: Peaceful, Normal and Hard mode. I think I don't have to explain the differences here do I? ;DFinally you set your starting point on a RGN map you can (gladly) re-roll to get better chances of the ideal settling spot.The gameplay:The gameplay might seem a bit too much at first (and even I did not know anything at the start... like jon snow) and I was confused by a lot but after I experimented a bit around I got the grip of it.NOTE TO RADIANT: We need a tutorial asap! (Now bacvk to the review)The starting goal is simple: Harvest some ressources to build workstations for your carpenter/potter. After that get some crates/boxes/stockpiles to gather the harvested ressources. And now you got everything you need to build your own buildings.The graphics:- Trove and Minecraft had a baby and this is the result: 3D-blockapolypse and I love it.>> I am currently still testing things and such and I am pretty fatigued atm. I gonna update this review over the next days <<My verdict (for now): 7/10 Good game to pass time and cool off from stress.The game is early access but it's worth the money trust me. More worth than No man's sky :'DThe content is small but the creativity is endles (see screenshots and artwork).If you like to play block-games and minecraft and love the trove-artstyle than this game is your game.Sincerely, Khillian R. Tesch

Posted: June 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is very addictive. It has the micro-management of a city building sim, but it's not on such a grand scale. However, it's kind of better, you get to know your village/town pretty well and you start to remember the names of who does what job and what they look like. It's great to just expand and grow out and you have the incentive of gaining new villagers through daily reports as you increase your net worth. Increasing the size of your population provokes attacks by increasingly difficult enemies, so you have to manage forces in to bands and promote footmen to knights or bowmen etc. The military system is enjoyable in that it allows the game to merge in to a military sim/strategy genre as well. I'm glad to see this game is doing well and that the developer is supporting it.Note, one warning: Bugs... Although this game is in early access, so I'll cut it some slack. I'm having a few bugs, e.g. soldiers not listening to commands, multiple glitches in custom building system, hearthlings not collecting loot and the inability to remove certain structures half way through building them.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								I cant really recommend this game since its so far from finished. But i've had so much fun with it i cant give it a "thumbs down" either.Its a colony building game in the same vein as Dwarf Fortress or Gnomoria. You designate the little people to be farmers or blacksmiths or whatever, designate a building here and a building there and, whenever they get around to it, they'll build it & live in it. Some of the fun details are that while the game has prefab buildings, you dont have to use them, you can opt to design your own instead. And if you come up with a good design you can save it to use again later. Eventually you'll be able to share your designs & others can use them in their colonies, which will be cool, but its not in yet.Theres a lot thats not in yet, if you read the design goals, the devs have a LOT in mind for this game. I'll be amazed if they can do half of it. But they keep working on it very steadily. Ive been following it for a long while now & updates & new features have always come in on a regular basis. The devs are very connected to the player community & it shows. Its certainly not another one of those "grab the money & run" fly-by-nights we've seen so many times on early access. These guys are serious about wanting to make a good game.If you like to use early access games to observe the game development process, this is a great game for that right now.  If you want it to, the game is happy to show you the nuts & bolts of exactly whats going wrong inside the AI's little brain when it gets stuck on a lamp post or whatever. And if you post a bug report, the devs will almost certainly have a fix in the next patch.However if youre the type who gets upset when you find yourself beta testing a game you paid for, perhaps skip this one for now... but keep an eye open for it, if/when it goes gold its gonna be really good!

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mined a 8x8 pit, forgot ladders, villagers got hungry and diedWould starve villagers again10/10Serious note:  This game is wonderful, Very kid friendly. Helps with imagination and pretty much build to your hearts content. I have had no complaint since kickstarter. Yes it has bugs, (some quiet funny/EA) but it is very playable and will drain your hours away. The dev's are very communicative. Tom even streams every Tues and Thrusday with the community and listen to your input. Well all of Team Radiant listen to the community.  They have well rounded road map too.PRO- Great city-building/RPG- Fun world- 10x better then most building games (and its EA)- Frequent updates, good developer communication- Easy going graphics (especially on low end machines)- Steady progressionCON- Villager professions not alot of them yet (part of the progress)- A.I. frustrations- Bugs here and there- Playing on story mode (no real story yet) can be difficult- Drains Time :) Little about how the game worksYou start off picking your location. Get a handful of villager (random gen - could get all females/males) with campfire and banner.  Beginning by getting mats (wood and stone) placing your stockpile for them to place. You promote for a Carpentar and hunter to get food going. Need to keep those villagers fed. Then to the Farmer to mass the food production. As your handling this you have your workers building houses, from scatch (or blueprint), placing beds (for them to sleep) and other items of decor. If in story mode, the goblins with attempt to bribe you or get you raided. Here comes your first footman. As time goes and and your life has drained away you will have walls up with footman patrolling keeping those pesky goblins and undead in check. Your village will be growing, your workers mining and working, your craftman crafting and your village having life. Quite a site to see.If your not into building villages, You can always go to peacful mode and build what you want. (I got a mages tower built floating in the air) But you can build almost what you want. As long as the villagers can reach it and build it. Still must keep them fed and have a place to sleep. But not much there but imagination.

number of helpful: 31 of 35 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								I know there are some negative reviews about this game, but I feel people aren't giving this game its due. Please remember it's in Alpaha still. Considering that, it is still amazing. Much of the work has gone into The Ascendancy(SP?). You start with 7 hearthlings in your group to found your new home. To gain more you must meet set amounts in food, morale, and net worth. Each of these can be done easily enough. You generaly meet morale unless you just don't do anythng for your hearthlings, like building beds to sleep in or chairs and tables for them to eat at or growing them at food. Food can be attained right away from berry bushes until you can make a farmer's hoe to promote a hearthling to farmer to grow food yourself. And net worth comes from building things like a shared sleeping quarters, dining hall, roads, or designing your own buildings. On day ten you'll be approached by a royal herald who will give you a quest to become a township. If you complete this quest you get tier 2 building materials.This game has entertained me for almost 200 hours already. My friends and I have to take turns using my PC just to play Stonehearth. At this time No Man's Sky is coming in second place to this game. We enjoy this so much.Many of the featurs of this game are unique. I have never played a game that allows me to manage, but not micro-manage. I give general commanda and the hearthlings live them out. It's a simulation game for a village. You build the village/town, but the hearthlings do it in their own way. You also have footmen/knights/archers/clerics to defend you town. Their are craftsmen of all sorts. It's an intricate system.Please get in on the ground floor and watch this game grow. This game will be huge, and it will be such an amazing release one of these days. Trust me.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
Early Access Review
CURRENTLY NOT RECOMMENDED FOR GENERAL GAMING. If you wish to help beta test this game, then I HIGHLY recommend it, because it has an incredible amount of potential and I want it to succeed and prosper. We need to help these devs do this by giving feedback and support.Completed my beta testing sessions on this game. Patience ran out (nothing personal...full time worker here lol). Here is the list of current bugs and frustrations I have run across.1. Excessive random encounters that make everything extremely difficult after around the 10th - 15th day. I just finished a session where, between game day 7 and 14, I was encountered by:-12 wolves-4 thieves-a goblin raiding party-4 zombies/skeletons (While I had 4 goblins raiding, thus citizens started dying left and right)-2 varnus things-a shiteload of those wood/stone gremlin thingsThis was on "Normal" mode, and in my opinion, this difficulty curve/cliff is a gamebreaker. It reduces the game from enjoyable cute fun, to frustration where I'm yelling at my screen "Give me a god damned CHANCE!" If the game is going to be enjoyable, I suggest deep, dynamic difficulty so players can modify the game to suit how they play. I'm a slow, meticulous gamer when it comes to games like these. I don't have time to ultra-micromanage everything, especially with very clunky unit management and controls. It's too difficult!2. Building anything is a hit-or-miss kind of experience. There are MANY bugs you'll encounter when trying to build anything larger than a small shack. Citizens giving up on buildings at random Not being able to delete walls at will. Only way to do this is the undo button, and that randomly stops working. So, essentially, if you build a wall that you don't like, or it's interfering with something, tough luck if it wasn't the most recent action you did. Frustrating. Not being able to build building parts in any order. Example: If you try to build too much of the interior before building the roof, you basically can't build a roof and your building is screwed. (See the above point) Custom walls seem to have a limited length. Doesn't make sense.3. Clunkiness of UI, and general controls.  A lot of menus, especially crafting menus, pull up tediously, and are delayed.  Moving troops around requires too many actions, which are also clunky. UI randomly disappears and even F5 doesn't bring it back up Too much clicking around!Everything else other than the above listed is going great. This game is one of my favourites ever, despite being incomplete, and I seriously hope the devs don't get lazy with it. That doesn't seem to be the case right now, because I'm constantly seeing bugfixes and updates. Support these guys! And one last request, when the game is released: Full mod support and API, so the community can grow the game, as well.Keep up the good work; I want to see this game surpass Minecraft in playability some day. I mean, imagine that...Going first-person and playing this game like you would minecraft, but you also have a dynamic town that NPCs build. You can go from first-person, to town management mode (Current setup). Isn't that something everyone has always wanted? Keep that one in mind. I'll return to testing at the Alpha 18 opt-in.

content:
Posted: January 7
Early Access Review
								Years ago, I had an enjoyable but brief relationship with Dwarf Fortress.  I really appreciated the randomly generated world, scenarios, and the continuously evolving gameplay, but my small lizard brain couldn't accept the ascii graphics.  I tried some graphical mods, but ultimately, Dwarf Fortress and I went our separate ways.  (I'm sorry Dwarf Fortress, it wasn't the size of your plump helmet that was the problem, it was me.)You're probably like, "Dude, stop talking about Dwarf Fortress. This is Stonehearth", and you're right, I shouldn't bring up past relationships, but Stonehearth scratches the same itch that kept me interested in playing Dwarf Fortress, and it looks perfectly adorable on top of it all.  Stonehearth isn't as in depth as Dwarf Fortress, but it is most definitely a Dwarf Fortress-like.  If you're like me, and you enjoyed Dwarf Fortress, but maybe the graphics bothered you or maybe you're looking for Dwarf Fortress Lite, Stonehearth may be worth buying.Keep in mind that this is an early access game, gameplay mechanics could change, things will break, and are broken in the game.  Consider your purchase as an investment in an evolving product, and the dev team!

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is one of those little games that make you feel like you're playing a SNES style RPG but in fact you're building the towns in said RPG and you get to see how the beginning was in said town. The goblin raids that went through your little village when you were nothing but a small team of builders trying to build up their first mess hall and houses for your people. How you were so helpless then and then near you complete your village and are happy with it you are very proud of it. The amount of time you spend and how much love and care you spent with each little villager with the classes and how you can see them work hard on any new structure you build from scratch. The game is beautiful for a voxel game with the cell shading and voxel enviroment. Now the game takes every block from the world. Terraforming is actually pretty pleasing in this game, instead of games in which terraforming is make or break, this game makes it realatively pleasing in which i never saw any ugly in doing so. If you have the money and are interested in buying this game, do so, you'll love it if you're into the micromanaging/ builder genre. I personally bought the game when it was $30 and was on a kickstarter. This was in Alpha 7, it was still buggy but they ironed it out and added much more content in the span of 3 months. Now, the game is still in Alpha, but neither the less I would buy it. It'll easily make you go a good 15 or so hours on your first town. Even if it's in Alpha, you still have a lot to do.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								In simple terms, the game is fun and worth it.All things considered, its an early access game, and we all know how those things can go. A quick pros vs. cons:PROS:- Good sound track- Challenging enemies- Easy to learn- Explorable land (treasures, enemy camps and farm animals can be found)- Many cool professions available for the citizens (each is unique and realistic)EXTRA (minor) PROS:- easy to loot- convenient tracker for citizens- fighters can be in their own seperate units (easy to navigate them)- can save and re-use building models (developer made buildings already available)- LADDERS* Can be extremely useful in debugging some builds and getting hearthlings unstuckCONS:- Lack of fighter categories (only 3 kinds + 1 kind of healer)- Several major bugs (Cizitens get stuck, buildings dont finish being built, scaffolding doesnt go away, CPU heavy when in windowed mode - Thankfully, they are not too frequent and are usually fixable with a quick restart)- Story is weak- No sign of actual friendly life visiting towns (besides dialogues)- Little motive to explore (if a friendly town was nearby to set up trade routes, id consider going FAR)With the cons, the game is still a solid 9/10 for how fun it is and for the price its offered at.As for the game itself, it is still being worked on and improved. As for now, the price point makes sense as there is still plenty of material to enjoy. I've played just over 30 hours and can definitely enjoy some more.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
A Sandbox Strategy That DeliversStonehearth is a sandbox strategy game, set in a (light) fantasy setting, with town building, crafting, and a military campaign.What Is It Like?Take Dwarf Fortress. Tone down some of the rogue-like elements. Replace the esoteric production chains and mood  simulations with more accessible and managable alternatives. Add a charming 3D voxel art style with tons of character. Introduce some truly innovative mechanics, including the way hearthlings simulate building. Voila.Or, for readers that haven't had the privilege of learning how "losing is fun", we'll try a more popular game for comparison. Take Minecraft, pull it back to  a strategic level, give yourself hearthlings to manage, add in a bunch of depth with jobs and production chains, and smother it in buckets of charm. Welcome to Stonehearth.What Sets It Apart From Other Sandbox Strategies?Charming and effective 3D voxel art style.Deep production chains that don't dive off the deep end (ie: stocking a hospital in Dwarf Fortress).Promotes mixing form with function through a powerful and versatile building creator/editor.Engaging, visually appealing, and immersive construction simulation.Deep, yet accessible, statistics and job system with fun role-playing elements.Interactive military campaign that allows the player to engage in diplomacy or war.Intelligent user-interface design maintains accessibility even in areas of the game with more complex mechanics.The Bottom LineI am recommending Stonehearth not only because it is already a successful sandbox strategy game in its own right, with truly innovative mechanics and an on-point blend of strategic depth and accessible fun, but because the small team at Radiant Entertainment have proven their exceptionalism. Since backing Stonehearth on Kickstarter I have enjoyed weekly updates, steady content addition that is continuously polished, and interactivity with multiple team members on their community forums. These guys care about making a great game, and it truly shows.Stonehearth is a game that is worth your money and time right now, as of Update 10.x, and one that will only improve in value as those updates continue rolling in.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								The one thing I must stress for those of you who are interested in this game is this: it is for all intents and purposes in early access. I know many of you have played early access games, and some of which were fully fleshed out games with minor bug fixes needed. THIS IS NOT ONE OF THOSE GAMES. As well as the numerous ui, ai and graphical errors there seems to be about 10 hours of expansive entertaining gameplay, after which you are left with a feeling of "what else can I really do". Now thats not to say that the devs have abandoned this game, in fact the situation is quite the opposite; there exists online a roadmap layed out of all the updates and new features they wish to add on. However as it currently stands I cannot recommend this game AS A STANDALONE TITLE. It doesn't have enough content to merit the $25 price tag, that doesn't mean you shouldn't purchase it: it means you shouldn't purchase it for what it currently is. If you buy this game it will be a game you have to revist it again and again in hopes that the devs actually deliver. So for right now I say wait, follow this title, add it to your wishlist etc. but don't purchase it yet.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								Very fun to play, almost zen-like.  The hearthlings are entertaining to watch as they go about doing their jobs.  A large part of the game play revolves around constructing facilities for your hearthlings to use, whether it be fields of carrot farms, large apartment complexes, intricate tunnel mines, imposing castle walls or simple homes for a peaceful village.   There are numerous jobs your hearthlings can learn, a basic research-tree allows players to explore new promotions each time you play the game.  It's currently not possible, or at least not easy, to have every job unlocked the first time you play it, so you will inevitably be tempted to start new towns to get the other jobs and try out new urban planning ideas.  It's very easy to get incredibly absorbed into the minutia, and obsess over the aethetics of your town.  Part of the fun is looking at what other people have built and getting inspired to construct your own version of real-world cities and towns.  Anyone who has an interest in architecture and interior design will easily become transfixed as this game has nearly an infinite possibilities that's only limited by your imagination.While your doing all this, the game does follow a very basic script of events that you'll need to prepare yourself for.  Mostly being attacked by goblin raiders and stray wolves that are mostly random, but builds up to a massive and inevitable showdown with Oggo's army of Orcs.  My largest complaint is that the Normal mode doesn't feel balanced because of this inevitable fight with Oggo's Army.The first time it happens, it can be quite a shock, as you've spent 10+ hours being completely consumed by the cute visuals and light-hearted game play, only to see your entire village basically swarmed by a massive army of Orcs who then ruthlessly slaughter all of your hearthlings (beating them to death with clubs).  The game does feature a "Peaceful" mode, ensuring a completely violence-free experience, but which also then negates the need to promote hearthings for combat-related jobs (Footman, Archer, Knight, Herbalist, Cleric).  However, it is a nice option to have.I don't just "like" this game... I love it.  I find the whole thing very endearing to play and would recommend this to anyone in a heartbeat.

Early Access Review
								I want to review StoneHearth not Hearthstone StoneHearth now StoneHearth is a game that looks like Minecraft but plays completely different and is by far one of the most enjoyable games I have ever played, let's start with the pros and move to the cons.Pro'sSo first off one of the best things about this game is the fact that you can sculpt and design your own civilization making this one of the best for role playing games yet one of the best Sim games.One of the coolest features of this game is that you can go ahead and build your own buildings from scratch and you can make your own Warriors and upgrade them using the crafting equipment you use you can fend off goblins and Invaders with your warriors and you can also trade with Traders and buy from Merchants that come to your town day and night.One of my favorite things to watch happen is my town progress and my citizens gain level's. You can even have people come to your town and reward you for killing off goblinsCon'sOne of the major issues with this game is the UI user interface it's extremely hard to work with, sometimes it glitches out and other times just completely shut's down and even makes you force shutdown the game.One of the things that also really irritates me is the constant lag that occurs that is unpreventable no matter how much you Tinker with the options internally and (externally, outside the game) you cannot fix the lag issues I personally have constant issues with completing buildings and helping my citizens survive from goblins invaders, because the lag is so horrendously bad.Now keep in mind this lag is so extremely hard to work around and it only starts when you progress into the game far enough. Errors will occur almost every single play-through and it really makes you wish that they had some sort of patch for people to work with instead they're going update by update.Thing's I want to see happenI wish that they would fix all performance issues and make it so your PC recognizes it as a game instead of a program.I want them to make an online multiplayer addition so you can play with AI or other players.I want them to make a campaign for story. Also add more action to the game so you can be full out assaulted and have to defend for like 5 minutes or longer.I want them to FIX something I did not mention above, which is when you ask a group of people to work on something new you can choose which citizens you wantr to work there so you have a spreadsheet. For example okay I want 3 citizens harvesting wood 7 citizens building a mansion and your guards to patrol in a certain pattern you choose.Also larger worlds, larger threats as you progress so it won't be a breeze to clear out 6 invaders with 1 guard(with a wooden sword)Other than that this game is FREAKING AWESOME. At it's current stage it's fantastic minus all the performance issues. 8.3/10

content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'll write this with the caveat that this game isn't finished being made at this time and is still in Alpha. That said, I wholeheartedly reccomend it. As a citybuilder/manegment game Stonehearth shows great promise and while it's a bit thin in its currect state (Alpha, so missing a lot of features/content) it's still pretty competent overall. Oddly, my favorite feature isn't the game itself, but the team behind it; Radiant. Those dudes have some of the best community outreach in the business and they are always putting out dev blog updates, keeping the content comming at a pretty good clip and letting you know what's on the horizon when they can't do that. It's cute, it's chirpy, it's got the foundation for a truly great town manager. I particularly love the ability to build custom buildings with relative ease, though style options are slightly limited, what with still being in development.There are a few Cons though; one, it's a slow game. Incredibly slow. Pace is apparently something on their list to work on, but as it is, I can only bear to play on fast and even then I feel like there should be a faster setting. There also aren't really any options for stockpile flow--the ability to have a particular stockpile pull from others, and it's one of the major things that's keeping Stonehearth from being truly great. This is also impacted by the speed (since your hearthlings have to walk AAAAALLL THE WAY to the stockpile, then ALLLL THE WAY back) which becomes more problematic as your town gets bigger. I imagine some of the problems I have will get resolved as the game works its way through Alpha, and I'll update this review as new things get added, problems arise, and good stuff crops up. If you're hard up for a city builder, I only see this one getting better over time. If you're a bit more skittish, that's fair; but keep at eye on this and I encourage you to give it a shot when it's more complete.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								**As a forewarning, there are minor spoilers. There really isn't much of a storyline, but I go in depth as far as gameplay goes.**So I spent a good few hours on the game, getting a feel and really seeing what it has to offer. The fact that it is in alpha was a little worrysome, given how many games are labeled with early access and seem to die without much improvement or support. This game, so it seems, is different. It's a refreshing change, it's truly quite unique in multiple aspects ranging from gameplay to art and design. This game is most certainly sandbox in nature, but it actually carries a very strong similarity to Dwarf Fortress, and almost seems like a branched-off, reskinned version of it. I can only imagine the vast amount of direction and improvement this game has in store if only the developers remain diligent and active.To start.. As of the current build -524, you have the option of choosing a biome, starting location, and race. I haven't experimented heavily with these options; I've only had the pleasure of one play in which I haven't come all that far. That being said, once you choose your world, you then choose where in said world you will build your camp. Naturally, you'll want to choose an area with plenty of trees, wildlife, and minerals. Upon choosing, you're dumped off without much of a tutorial, which usually seems like an overwhelming experience, however.. This game is fairly straight foreward. After a few minutes, I quickly learned my way around the UI, the different tools, navigation, and issueing commands to my Hearthlings. Before long, the first raid on my settlement had taken progress. I immediately knew the general idea of what to do, click the large, red sword icon, right? It was as simple as that; my Hearthlings ran to a safe position as my assigned soldiers made short work of the beast. As of right now, the game doesn't seem to be too unforgiving. I am expecting that to change as I come further along and mine deeper into the ground.Graphically speaking, this game is very crisp and clean. There are a few annoyances which are more gameplay issues than graphics, but I'll get to those in a bit. The game has a bit of a minecraft appearance, but one with customer shaders and higher quality picture. Textures are almost non existant, but I can do without those, it simply works for this game. All in all, there isn't a whole lot of clutter, which can really turn into a big problem for games like this.In terms of bugs, this game definitely has its share, but it's to be expected. I feel confident that more and more bugs will be fixed as time continues, the support website seems very much alive with devs attempting to help those who experience issues. A few bugs I've personally come across include goblins exploding into sunlight instead of fighting my soldiers, a Hearthling that never wakes up from his sleep, and not being to change to a specific class despite having met all requirements. Obviously two of these can be considered game breaking, however I'm not letting it kill my opinion of this game. Save often is the best fix for most problems.As for one final in-depth review, this game is, as I mentioned, like a replica of Dward Fortress, though with FAR less features. I suspect this game is very heavily influenced by Dwarf Fortress. You have the ability to custom-build structures, or choose from a preset list. You can place said structures where ever they fit. You can alter the environment by taking down trees, creating mines, etc. As you create mines, it really opens up many different possibilities for construction ideas. Perhaps an underground fortress? All in all, in the short amount of time that I've played this game, I'm enjoying it a lot. If they can implement some more features or similarities from DF such as complex contraptions, many more monsters and biomes, etc, I'll be thrilled. Perhaps even a mode to take complete control of a single, hero-like individual to explore the lands, loot, plunder dungeons, and seek bounties, much like DF. I might be going a little far comparing the two, but regardless, the game can (hopefully) only improve from here.

Early Access Review
								I have a lot of games in my steam library but this is the one I keep coming back to. This is the kind of game I can lose myself in, starting a play session, getting really focused on building and defending my town, and then I look at my clock and 6 hours have somehow gone by. The latest focus on combat and hardmode have brought a much more intense feeling to the game. Enemies can catch you offguard if you don't think about all angles you need to defend, and the new RPG classes have added a lot of depth to the combat side of the game. As far as developing your town/fort/city-whatever goes I becom a kid again, playing with lego.This is in alpha, so there are still a lot of glitches, missing features, and polish that is getting fixed/added. Building elaborate structures is usually very difficult especially getting the hearthlings to construct them. You can cheat structures in with console commands, but hopefully some day you won't ever need to use commands again and the little guys will be able to make anything you want.One of the best things about this game is it's devs. They are very community focused and they actually stream on twitch coding and art sessions three times a week. They aren't very active on the steam community hub, but on their own website's discourse they are very active.I really recommend this game even in it's current alpha state. Very enjoyable building game with some decent RTS RPG style gameplay.

Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a brilliant game considering that it is an early alpha. If you've ever play'd a game called 'RimWorld' It's much like that. Stonehearth is like a village management game, you gain a new civ every night [If you reach the days goal E.g. Enough wealth, Happiness & Food] This goal is meant to get harder as the game goes on, but it isn't really that hard to reach.Con's-The building in Stonehearth could use some improvements and I'm sure the developers will make this mechanic better. Once you place a building it cannot be removed.-You are not able to build easily inside E.g. In a cave/ Mountain.-When the goblins start to raid, it seems like they never stop coming night after night. They could use tuning down [Spawning less]Pro's-So far I have experienced very little lag, to fix this all I did was re-load the game.-There're soo many options for the civ's. For example you can appoint them different jobs such as Warrior, Cook, Farmer, Trapper... Each with a new set of uniform & tools.-Very attractive game. Although the graphics are not Arma 3 standard, it doesn't need to be - the games graphics suit the game, the blocks have near enough a plain texture and puts less strain on your PC. -When your village does get attacked, It's not like a few games out there, where you're entire village would get destroyed Age Of Empires, I'm looking at you here.I've stopped playing StoneHearth for now, not because It's a bad game but because I'm waiting for more items to be implemented into the game.
