Every little hearther is happy, at peace and happy in life as we press further into the hillside, ever expanding, handing out food to passing merchants - we have plenty- in exchange for fancy chairs and rustic fire pits for the long houses. We gather to eat and jest, then sleep in simple beds with roaring fires to keep us warm.This is simple. Peaceful. This is Edoras.Ok, I'll be truthful, i was expecting a quick hour or so to get into it, set up farms, housing... basic stuff then just steam roll it for a half hour then refund it cause i wasn't enjoying it.But no, Stonehearth has this... charm to it that i just can't pinpoint. Maybe it's the building system - you have a few preset designs and the rest you can build using a fairly simple but effective system of drag selections and semi voxel based building -, maybe it's the constant strive to better your town and lure more hearthers (little voxelly pixelly villagers) into your town for workers.Maybe you just enjoy the sense of wonder of seeing your town flourish by your hand.Stonehearth is probably already worthy of a release, i don't even begrudge them £18.99 because the game is truly extremely fun. BUT One problem is... The AI... the hearthers are a little... single minded, monkey see, monkey do sort of thing. Like place desings for a house... they start building. Good. Place designs for another hosue and a... idk, a storehouse, and sometimes theyll  all flock to build the storehouse and begin construction. So that house you placed first unless you reinstate the build order, will become last priority. Not bad as such, just a little... irritating seeing half built buildings (storehouse and blacksmith in my village) being used and slept in with no roof, half a wall missing, and no door.. :pPersonal peeve and i'm sure others will feel the same way...

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								Only five hours in but I'm having a TON of fun, and it's only in alpha.THE QUICK VERSION: Do you like Gnomoria (or Dwarf Fortress)? Do you like Minecraft? If you answered "yes" to either of these, you'll most likely enjoy this game. If you answered "yes" to both, you'll DEFINITELY enjoy this game.THINGS TO LIKE:+ The building system is the most robust of any citybuilder I've seen to date. You not only get to lay out buildings for your Hearthlings to construct (very intuitively, in my experience!) but you get to place furniture within and without at your whim. There's already a great deal of different types of furniture and decor your Hearthings can craft.+ The music is excellent. It's rich and well composed, and it gives the game a very quaint feel.+ Game generation is simple but fun and really makes you feel like you're having an impact on your game before it even starts. You roll a set of Hearthlings, each with their own stats, and can even name them. You also get an amount of gold to spend on a selection of items to start yourself off with. You select your options in storybook form when the game asks you to pick between two types of Hearthlings (one medieval-ish group and one nomadic, desert-like group), two types of biomes (temperate or desert), and two types of game (either you can be raided by enemies or you can't). Then your map is generated and you select where on that map you want to settle. Each region has access to different resources.+ Trade events. Just about every day, a trader will come by offering different deals. You can buy or sell certain goods from some, some will ask you to make them x number of items then come back after a set amount of time to trade you something agreed upon for them... It keeps things fresh and gives you new ways to get resources you maybe don't have access to based on where you settled.+ Hearthling jobs. There are several different jobs in the game and they all feel useful. Every Hearthling starts off as a basic laborer, who can only gather resources, haul them, or build. With items (most of which are constructed by the various crafting jobs), you can promote a hearthling to any number of other jobs such as Farmer, Carpenter, Tailor or Trapper. Every job has levels that increase as your Hearthling performs that job and gains experience. At each tier, a new ability is unlocked. These range from increased speed to the ability to randomly create high-quality furniture that takes on a finer appearance than the base item being crafted. Many jobs are also laid out in a tree wherein you must have a Hearthling of level x in one job to promote to another. For example, Cook requires Farmer at level 3.+ The ability to save your building designs for easy placement later.THINGS THAT NEED WORK:- Currently it's very difficult (possible though!) to build a second floor that functions. I'm sure this will be ironed out as the game plods along in development, though.- A few of the job abilities aren't implemented yet, but this will definitely be remedied later just on nature of the status being "not implemented".- You get occasional errors when trying to do things, pretty much always in regards to building. They haven't crashed the game for me, it's basically just the game telling me the engine didn't understand what I was trying to do.- Sometimes the building bugs a bit, but all that generally means is that you have to cancel building and start designing from the start again. Bit of a pain, but with trial and error, you'll get where you're going, and this is sure to be ironed out in the long term.FINAL VERDICT:It's already an incredibly addictive game for me. In its current state, I'd rate the game a solid 7.5/10. It has the potential to be at LEAST a 9. If for whatever reason you trust my opinion, I'd tell you this game is worth the buy right now. It's one of the sharpest alpha states I've ever seen for a game and there's already so much to enjoy and lose hours in. Five hours in, I've only scratched the surface of jobs and the like and I'm still going strong. I can see myself easily logging over 100 hours in this thing.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been excited for Stonehearth since the Kickstarter which I happily contributed to. I saw a team of people who were passionate about delivering the product they envisioned instead of a watered down version.Two years later I'm happy to see that I wasn't wrong. The development team is very transparent, honest, and are not willing to give up on their vision like so many other games have. Unfortunately, that means that some things take longer to do and have more bugs because the implementations are more complex. I've watched and played the alphas, though, and I've seen fantastic and surprisingly rapid growth so I'm optimistic about where this game will be when it's finally complete.Worth the price, but please remember this is alpha-quality software so there may be some frustrations. Alpha 10 is pretty stable but if you'd like to avoid some of the game-breaking issues that can sometimes pop up I would wait a few more versions or even until Beta when the real bug fixing kicks in.

content:
Posted: February 3
Early Access Review
								This is a very satisfying game with a rather cute artstyle that scratches all the itches that towns left me with.Essentially, you indirectly command a small village of settlers to build up a town, attract new residents, and defend your town from raids by wolves, zombies, goblins, kobolds, and all sorts of similarly nasty monsters.The game, unfortunately, can be quite straining on your computer when you have a lot of villagers, but since I've started playing, the game's performance and optimisation have both improved dramatically. When I started playing, the game would get completely bogged down at around 20 villagers and they would stand around doing nothing until they starved, now I can have 30 villagers comfortably and the game only gets a little clogged after playing for several (8+) hours with that number of villagers.The developers are also very communicative and active and chat with the community regularly to take suggestions and feedback. If you enjoy citybuilding and sandboxy games then I really can't recommend this game enough.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is much like a city builder, but with some RPG/Adventure elements in it. The goal is to keep your Heartlings, or citizens alive by finding resources, building houses and defences and fighting off invaders. When I first got into this game I had a hard time getting used to it. There were many game breaking bugs that got your Heartlings stuck or buildings that could not get finished. Most of the bugs have been fixed and you won't run into any for the most part. The ones that do are often easily shrugged off.UiThe game is quite easy to get into. The UI is quite easy to handle and you can easily access any information you might need. Important events like raids, level-ups or traders will pop up and notify you of their arrival. You can "slice" the ground  so you can see your mines underground and the same can be done for the buildings (although this might need some improvement for buildings with multiple floors). BuildingBuildings can be made in any way you want as these can be build much like Minecraft block by block. After you're finished editing your building you can let your Heartlings build it for you. The game also offers some blueprint for you when you don't feel like building houses yourself and these too can be edited to your liking. When building starts your heartlings will get everything they need to build the structure bit by bit. They even build scaffolding to make the building making it cool to see your buildings being build from the ground up.ProfessionsYour heartlings will be able to be given specific roles. Like a carpenter, a farmer or a footman. This will allow them to level up in this respective tree which in turn will allow you more to make and progress your town further. Each role has their benefits and are overall very well balanced out. You will mostly want to have all of them every time.ChallengesWhile supplying your town with supplies is not hard all on its own, it does get a bit more exciting when enemies start appearing. Having to call back your citizens to the safety of your building while your footmen, knights, archers and clerics move in to take care of the threat. Combat is really fun, even when it's this simple it still gets you to hold your breath sometimes when its a close call for one of your soldiers. StoryThe game does not have much story going on yet. But it is easy to see the potential the game has and the devs are working on the story as we speak. Which brings me to the next part.DevelopmentNow, many people have been complaining about how slow the game has developed over the last months. And I can't blame them. But one thing you must keep in mind is that the development team is a small one. Personally I still back the dev team as they seem to actually care about the game.My overall opinionI like this game. Quite a bit. It is a bit like minecraft but more strategy based. Which I like. The game's theme is great. Very cute and playful making even the biggest fights look cute and huggable. The game still lacks some contend but even now I would pay my 30 bucks for it and think it money well spent. I love the system of the game and the way it works. The UI is simple and much to my liking. My only real downside is that I too would wish for more content being thrown out more rapidly. I give this game a 8/10. Some might say this is way too high. But you just cant deny this game is a lot of fun and still has a whole lot of potential. I hope the game gets some big updates in 2017 and I feel like the devs will deliver on this. My advice? Buy this game! Support these developers. It's small companies like these that make the greatest games. If given the chance.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								What can I say? This game is just a ton of fun. I soaked up 4 hours playing this when I first bought it. If you like town/city builders, and like to manage colonies and the like, then this game is right up your alley. I thought that the art style would bug me at first, but to be honest, it is kinda nice. You don't get caught up in the graphic nature being a big point in the game, even though you can make some nice loking buildings and stuff anyway.Stonehearth looks like Minecraft, but plays very differently. It is in a top down-ish format, so you aren't controlling a single character, but rather managing what the colonists will work on. I won't go too much into the mechanics of such a game, as it isn't the first to do such a thing, but it is worth noting that you don't have IMMEDIATE control over what the colonists do, unless they are doing nothing at the time.This is an amazing game. I can only assume it will get even better, and it looks as though the devs intend to stick with it, fixing some annoying bugs already. If you are on the fence, I'd say just buy it, give it the 2 hours to decide, and if you don't find yourself completely wowed by it, Steam will give you a refund. You really can't go wrong here.

content:

Early Access Review
								I've been following Stonehearth for years, and finally picked it up on Steam.  It's a very fun game for passing the time.  You have partial control over your hearthlings by giving them tasks and telling them to walk to certain areas.  The rest is handled by the AI.  But once you have 20 hearthlings doing their thing you have plenty to do.  There are multiple job paths and little mini quests along the way.  Buildings can be custom designed as well or you can use some of the pre created cookie cutter models.The game is still in alpha but its looking very good and is very playable as it is.Another massive pro is their support!  I had one issue and they immediately replied and had several team members assisting me.  After some other recent Alpha flops I can't tell you how reassuring that is!!!  Very much appreciated.I hope this game only gets better and better!

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Rewrote this Review due to new updates, current Stable: Alpha 17, but Alpha 18 is playable and looking good too. Previous Review had 4 of 7 Helpful votes.Short Version: It's still a Dwarf Fortress/Gnomoria style game, but less focused on deep digging and more on exploration, crafting, and building. Class System is simple but interesting and more unique than simply assigning jobs, and much more user friendly than most. Don't let the simplicity fool you though, you can pour some fair time into this if you like these kinds of games.Since my previous review, it's still in Alpha, but has resolved or at least lessened alot of the Optimization issues, with more tweaks focused on that to come - judging by the dev blog and their videos, they genuinely care about fixing this, and they should since 2d Dwarf Fort lags up pretty bad once you have a big enough population going, imagine how bad it's going to be in a 3d game like this. Smart focus on their part, one of the rare devs that learns from others' issues, unlike every MMO dev out there.The AI is much better now, though still a little prone to bad decision-making. You can somewhat "control" their pathfinding by building Roads, as it favors those almost exclusively unless no road exists to follow nearby. The Building issues I had before seem resolved for the most part, though I'll still find a ladder or scaffolding stuck floating and undestroyable without using the Console.Combat has advanced by leaps and great bounds since my previous review - many more weapon/armor options, as well as 3 new classes: the Knight, with heavier armor and 1h/shield focus, bonus defense/stats and buff auras for his allies, as well as Taunt skills to protect the squishies - the Archer, your standard ranged attacker who can either slow or burn enemies based on their Arrow Quiver equipped(and double-shot at max lvl) - and most importanly, the Cleric, a Healer Monk who can do melee dmg and defend himself but puts their first priority as healing any nearby units with damage, both directly and through a passive aura. I make 2 groups of 1 of each class and it protects my bases pretty well + deals with the Story armies nicely.The Mining system is a little more controllable now but still not as fine-tuned as I would like to see, and usually see in other games of this kind - there's no Ramps or Stairs to be dug, and manually digging them up doesn't usually work because the AI prefers to build and use Ladders instead of stepping up/down 1 block steps.Overall they're making nice strides in the right direction, and I'm eager to see more.Bonus: There's already a decent-sized Mod community, and they make some pretty good mods so far, from whole new classes and items to entire Biomes(The Archipelago one is awesome)

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								I really do love the concept of this game.  The game has settlers left in the wilds to fend for themselves.  They slowly start to learn the basics to create their own city and a home for themeslves.At this point, though, the game is not ready.  The bugs are hard to get over and the game has not been updated to handle 'end of game' content or what happens when you level.  I build a place for everyone to sleep, to eat and then I'm pretty much done.  I have everyone collect resources, but really this only happens sometimes.  My blacksmith or Mason level up to create new things for my settlement, but I'm unable to impliment them, I don't see a reason to use them, and I can't make my own due to glitches.  Now I don't want you to stray from the basic game.  Despite this all, as I frist stated, the game is headed in the right direction and I hope it continues that way.  If the developer can pull this all together I think we'll have a huge hit on our hands a game I won't be able to stop playing.I do think the game is worth a try!  Watch out for the goblins!

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've always been big on strategy games (since mid-late 90s) where you build your base, army, and go off killing those who try to kill me, such as command & conquer series, age of empires series, stronghold series and more.  I saw this game, "Stonehearth", on Kickstarter and just loved the whole concept.  they even had a great goals display to show you what their plans are.  Now I was skeptical to even put my money down because I was afraid they will just stop eventually and disappear like a great game that had potential, (The Stomping Land).I must say I’m very happy to have put my money in and then support them.  I played it since the beginning, even though I only have a total of about 15hrs, I just fell in love.  I stopped playing so that it can come up with better fixes, changes like any newly forming games.  I played it recently within few months and my goodness, it's even better!  they even have a dev map and objectives! I love it!Honestly, I highly consider this game to anyone that likes this whole minecraftish, base building, survival sandbox.  you can wait to buy it later or buy now, still great.  the dev's constantly work on this, they don't quit, they find more issues and fix them. they show videos on what they are working on, their issues they've encountered and so on.  I’m glad I put my money into this game.  i know in few months, this will become better than it is now with the speed and dedication all these workers put in.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								StoneHearth has a very "cutesy" and "family friendly" look to it, and has a good and wide range of genres mixed together. its a great game for kids and adults alike.now the game is not "feature complete" or anything like that, it still has a lot of content to be added, but dont worry the devs wont give up, and most certaintly will finish the game.word of warning, the game is still very buggy. but then again that is the entire point of an alpha, squash the bugs and add awesome content. if you dont like the idea of playing a game that has lots of bugs and potential to crash, then this game is not for you. however if you love being right up front helping the devs hunt down and squash those bugs, then i recomend this game.Edit: it's been over a year since i reviewed this game, and i gotta say, Stonehearth has come a looonng way since my original review. the game has a ton of new features: new playable race, new monsters and campaigns, bunch of new classes, perfomrance improvements. and a bunch of other good stuff. and yes, there are still bugs and some crahses, but they'tend to be less frequent as before.so even after a year, i'd still recomend this game to anyone who likes town/city builders, early acces games, finding/reporting bugs, and being part of a great and friendly comunity.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth; the strategy survival game that isn't to be confused with Hearthstone. Now this is a great game and although it still lies within the grasps of "EARLY ACCESS" it has much potential that i can see it achieving in the future. With a very proud company stood behind it (Radiant) it is always improving, updating and upgrading your experience. However there are downsides to this game still being in early access. One being that the game still has many bugs which torment you throughout gameplay. One of my examples is the building bugs, now to begin i must say when i first saw this game i invisioned in my mind a huge expanding town with tall walls and a vast amount of buildings. Needless to say when i started designing and trying to create my own buildings i came up with one of the greatest problems. Buildings are at this point (alpha 16) really difficult to design without your heathlings (Settlers) just simply giving up mid-way. Now this is an issue that the company is working hard to address and you can see they are via their YouTube channel but still makes me suffer when trying to play this game how i want to play it. With other minor bugs that still annoy me throughout playing i still really enjoy this game and i love the abilities it has right now and is still improving! This game has so much to it and just to summarise:- Lots of different skills and professions- Tons of dynamic and varying enemies - Beautiful unique graphics- A world to explore and settle within - Over 100 items and resources to useI only have about 20 hours of gameplay (as of writing this review) but hope to get many more out of new alpha releases and maybe one day we will see this game be complete after its polished as this game could be great but falls short due to bugs and problems. Maybe consider supporting the creators to keep working on the game and give it a try.Would recommend! :)

								Normally I'd caution against "early access" games as a trap *Cough* Ark *Cough* but this game is truly loved by its developers and its fans. Over the time I've owned this game, I have seen it really grow and thrive. You'd be supporting a great project that you WILL be able to see positive growth in. The game itself is a marvelous charing little sandbox game, so if that's what you're into then give Stonehearth a go!

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								I kickstarted this game when it first showed up on kickstarter back in 2013.  It looked like a game with a lot of heart, and I believe it shows even in the early access stage.This game reminds me of Minecraft due to its graphical style and its voxel based world.  It however runs with the idea of building a civilization out of a small group of starting "hearthlings" as they are called.  You start with just a group of "hearthlings" and some supplies and then are tasked with creating a thriving kingdom from that.There are also a decent amount of mods available that add objects or campaigns to the game and they are worth checking out once you have some experience with the vanilla game.While there is not a lot of content in the game right now it is a fun little game that you can mess around with.  The updates seem to be more frequent now that the games development has hit the add content/fix bugs stage.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm going to give a cautious thumbs up to this game. It is still very much in Early Access and it shows. There are bugs, unfinished features, very little documentation...pretty much everything you'd expect for a game still in active development.For all that, the devs are very active and quite open about where they are in the process and what they are working on. Much more than most other developers I've followed. It's reassuring to see things go up on their list and bits check checked off as features are added in.And what it does have already is quite fun and I find it rather addictive. Despite a few crashes and failed villages due to bugs, I keep coming back for more. There is just something so engrossing and relaxing about this game, I can't seem to make myself give it up!Personally I'm quite excited to see where it is going, and I think it is going to just get better and better.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
Early Access Review
Review: Alpha 10TL;DR:Do you like games like: Cultures The Settlers 1-4 (Before the serie was butchered) Castle Story City/Town Management games Designing thingsThen this is for you.More about the game:This is a sweet little gem of a game. The play-style is very much as a Cultures-like game, where you give your citizens a profession, which they get better at/more experience with. And then they can learn the next step of the profession tree. As an example Trapper(Hunter), who get's the bright idea that, "Hey, i can just have animals in a pen, don't have to run around setting traps". Much like how it works in Cultures, but you do not have any direct control over your citizens besides assigning them jobs. Some jobs, needs a workbench placed (Click on the citizen you have assigned a job to set a workbench), from there you can order items that the worker will make over time. The more they make, the more they can learn to make, some items can also be "Fine" which looks nicer.Any citizen that dosen't have anything to do, will help build buildings, mine, gather items and cut trees if given the general order (You select areas to mine/cut trees, which then whoever got time for it goes to do it). The games building system is pretty smart, tho still needs some slight work. Easy to build, place the floor. Auto-snap walls, auto-snap roofs, manually placed windows and doors. But the game also offers building templates, so just click and drop more or less(Works well if you don't want to use time building fancy buildings).There are currently two game modes, one which has enemies (Normal) and one without any dangers (Peaceful). The game is not very challenging just yet. Tho it might be a good idea to try out peaceful, just to get the general hang of things before heading into normal.The game itself looks great, very aesthetically pleasing, the characters look charming, smooth animations, pretty great character variety, trees have different ages and sizes. Terrain looks nice, eventho slightly plain right now. Will be looking forward to a bit more variation.Currently the game is in need of optimization, but that is something that will come along, especially since this is still in a early alpha. Alpha is all about adding new features and stuff for you to do. Optimization mostly comes from the beta. If you get a low framerate, i highly recommend turning down shadows if you have some performance problems.Conclusion:Personaly i really love it, it is a solid city-builder/managing, with some added rpg and combat. I know city-building isen't for everyone, but this is a great entry into the genre.Worth buying, if unsure, take a look at some gameplays!

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Sadly rare when a Kickstarter game lives up to expectations, but when it does happen they usually knock it out of the park. Stonehearth is one of those rare long-term Kickstarters which I've never regretted for a moment. The dev team is always responsive, the game is constantly evolving, and the community isn't as vile as a lot of toher builder games. It's an easy recommendation for a more casual building-focused DF-like. It's going to be a long haul for these guys as they get everything in this game that they envision, but it's worth every build!

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								8-5-16I've had this game for a very long time and have seen it come a long way, here are my gripes at this point that have prevented this game from being great and finally landing a negative review:They have kept the game "playable" throughout development which was a plus, fixing critical bugs along the way as well but the game, from the beginning, could not function past 4-6 hrs of playing because of poor optimization. This really limits the whole idea of this game and really enjoying the full potential of having your own little town. Another area of "soreness" has been the pathfinding AI, it has never really been great to begin with even with all of the improvements to it over development. The maps are quite small in reality and more people would complain as well if you could play long enough on one without having to restart. Another reason of really wondering where this game is going or what the final product will become.Until huge leaps of optimization and pathfinding find its way to this game, I'm going to have to say wait till a sale or more updates centered around these issues.

content:
Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
My OpinionStonehearth is fun game of Village construction and management. As the Devs said, it does remind me a lot of DnD or other fantasy worlds and universes. The Hearthlings all have their own streangths and weeknesses, but if you have too many they do start to seem quite similar. The building prossess for buildings, wall, canals, and bridges works quite well, allowingyou to build something simple and quickly, or complex and intricate over a period of time. The only issue with it is that on occasion the Hearthlings seem to stop building for no reason, causing you to have to save the blueprint and start over from the begining of construction hoping that it doesnt stop again. Rarely, they might accidentally trap themselves inside a buildings walls and starve to death because of this. Its more annoying then game breaking, but it is something the devs need to fix.The world that the Hearthlings can go to build a new home is quite diverse. Ore dominating the mountains while plants and fertile land dominates the lowlands. It cause you to have to think about where you settle at the start, as you dont want to send your Hearthlings too far from the saftey of your town. Goblins, Orcs, Entlings, Stoneling and more roam the forests and mountasins to attack, set up camps, and steal your stuff, providing quite the challange to defend your Hearthlings and stuff.Pros+Nice art that compliments theme of game+Monsters provide challange untill later game when you have a decent military and can deal with everything thrown at you+Animations on Hearthlings and Monsters make them have personallity and express feelings+Easy to use building system that is an, "Easy to learn, difficult to master" type of thing+fun and easy to come back to gameplay+Really helpfull devs that actually care about their work and the issues their players are havingCons-Building is buggy at times, but it is still in alpha, so this isn't as bad-Hearthlings are utterly stupid and keep putting themselves in dangerous situations sometimes and not at others with the same command issued to them-Mechant stalls only seem to get the basic merchant types and not special or more specialised onesFinalFor a game in Alpha, it is incredibly far along for what it is. Many of the games core mechanics are implamented, and the game is a blast. I personally cant wait for Multiplayer, Magmasmiths, Geomancers, the Expanded story quests, visiuallised travaling merchants, Transportation options, the Rabbit clan, alternate planes, Dwarves, titans, more construction parts and decor, the combat system expansion, and all the other stuff the Devs are planning on adding over the versions. Stonehearth is game game I would reccomend to everyone.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								After 7 tries, I've finally become comfortable in combat mode. I've got three levels consisting of farming, mining, and housing. There's a slight learning curve, but once you overcome it; it becomes beautiful. I really like Banished, and this mixes between banished and minecraft in a way that is Stonehearth. I've tried a lot of games in search of this feel and finally found it. Manage your village by managing your people and you can create wonders. I can't wait for the polished product.To the devs/design, there have been a few quirks with building, but I've learned to save often and reload my UI (F5). The save UI is a bit difficult to see, maybe and image bar on the right with a listing of saves that loads images on selection. Another note; the auto save feature seems to cause some issues with a couple of my games until I turned it off. I'll navigate the forums for defects of similar nature and post accordingly.Request: Allow prerequisite resource building for something that requires a base item. (eg. Creating multiple worker outfits will automatically create the required items if you have it, otherwise don't allow to create).A guard HAS to start with a wooden practice sword? I had better gear ready for the promotion, yet he required the wooden sword to promote. Anyways, if the max defense/attack item is available in stock, then equip that ish.I held off building; buildings. The reason was because in my last game, the doors, windows, and such were applied to the physical building, but not in the building completion list. I then decided not to care about building finalization until the workers took down the outer ladders.Speaking of outer ladders, I planted some trees nearby and they grew quite large. While building the tower, the top of the tree was used as a surface. The issue is that the ladder could not then be taken down. I failed at cutting down the tree to see what happens.Users: Use auto-save with caution. Scoring Card That Shouldn't Matter because you need to play it to say it---Coding: 9/10 ((on point)-1)Graphic Design: 8/10 (Hits pretty hard at high settings on my nVidia GTX 970, switched to medium for a more chill and netflix feel and I'm happy with the settings. I still need to tinker, but this game has got me so interested in it.)User Interface: 9/10 (Happy with the UI! Nice work!!! A recommendation would be to differentiate between: available to make AND available to make with current mats.)Heads Up Display: 9/10 (some errors while displaying multiple UI frames/panels/grids at the same time.)Replayability: 8/10 (Re-reviewablity too)Building: 8/10 (I really wish I were able to include a ladder within the blueprint, or invent stairs :- )Story: 7/10   (the goblins were funny, I was hoping they would build into a village that I could trade with or assist and potentially incorperate into my society, providing my village with extra benefits for assisting the goblins instead of goblin posts [that I placed in front of my outbound gates to ward off any stragler goblins that don't know what's up])Loading: Fast/10Simplicity: Somewhat/10Hour Spent/Day: 1/3Saying that this game is better than your nephew's minecraft game: pricelessGet----My LevelTips:- Study the HUD and defend your stuff. I got lucky and traded poo for 2 copper armor that got me through battles early game.- Upgrade your guards!- Farm it all (I always have at least 2 farmers, then when one is ready for Cook, I'll bring in another farmer once I've promoted the farmer to Cook.)- Build everything! Also, once your guards upgrade, you'll have gear to sell, but save some for the next recruit!!- Blueprints are pretty cool! I made a simple 1 story empty shop for the different shops. I'm about to make a blueprint for each craft. :)- I started at the 2nd level of ground from a lake, 1 story up is stone, so I get the whole shibang.- I'm still trying to get my blacksmith to level 6 so I can craft a gold chest that can hold 256 items. Nice number btw.- I went without a carpenter for a while to have a couple of workers at least- When creating a new game; get the farmer, weaver, and guard items (hoe, spindle, and wooden practice sword)- I haven't noticed any speed increase in having paths, so I use them as asthetics. You'll need the weaver to make a bunch of winter outfits (I'm still in Spring and my workers wear the Winter gear for the speed increase)- QuestionsQ: I haven't hit winter yet; should I expect to have a warm environment built, outside and in?A: My hope: Yes, you're screwed.Q: How long are the seasons? A: 30 days. Just hit dewmon (2nd) :)My theory: 90 days per season, give or take a fewQ: Why do I like this game so much?A: It exceeded my expectations and continues to ensure playabilityOverall (tl;dr), I will give this game an 8.33/10 in its current state and would recommend this to anyone. In fact, I'm about to send it to a friend.

My OpinionStonehearth is fun game of Village construction and management. As the Devs said, it does remind me a lot of DnD or other fantasy worlds and universes. The Hearthlings all have their own streangths and weeknesses, but if you have too many they do start to seem quite similar. The building prossess for buildings, wall, canals, and bridges works quite well, allowingyou to build something simple and quickly, or complex and intricate over a period of time. The only issue with it is that on occasion the Hearthlings seem to stop building for no reason, causing you to have to save the blueprint and start over from the begining of construction hoping that it doesnt stop again. Rarely, they might accidentally trap themselves inside a buildings walls and starve to death because of this. Its more annoying then game breaking, but it is something the devs need to fix.The world that the Hearthlings can go to build a new home is quite diverse. Ore dominating the mountains while plants and fertile land dominates the lowlands. It cause you to have to think about where you settle at the start, as you dont want to send your Hearthlings too far from the saftey of your town. Goblins, Orcs, Entlings, Stoneling and more roam the forests and mountasins to attack, set up camps, and steal your stuff, providing quite the challange to defend your Hearthlings and stuff.Pros+Nice art that compliments theme of game+Monsters provide challange untill later game when you have a decent military and can deal with everything thrown at you+Animations on Hearthlings and Monsters make them have personallity and express feelings+Easy to use building system that is an, "Easy to learn, difficult to master" type of thing+fun and easy to come back to gameplay+Really helpfull devs that actually care about their work and the issues their players are havingCons-Building is buggy at times, but it is still in alpha, so this isn't as bad-Hearthlings are utterly stupid and keep putting themselves in dangerous situations sometimes and not at others with the same command issued to them-Mechant stalls only seem to get the basic merchant types and not special or more specialised onesFinalFor a game in Alpha, it is incredibly far along for what it is. Many of the games core mechanics are implamented, and the game is a blast. I personally cant wait for Multiplayer, Magmasmiths, Geomancers, the Expanded story quests, visiuallised travaling merchants, Transportation options, the Rabbit clan, alternate planes, Dwarves, titans, more construction parts and decor, the combat system expansion, and all the other stuff the Devs are planning on adding over the versions. Stonehearth is game game I would reccomend to everyone.

content:
Posted: January 12
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a great game by Radiant. This is one of the best purcheses I have made on steam. It's a nice city building game unlike any other! Monsters will attack your colony of hearthlings, but if you're not into the stuff, you can turn them off. The UI is great and it's fun to watch your colony grow to a threiving city. Another really cool thing is that I feel more conected with my hearthlings in Stonehearth then I do my villagers in Banaished or workers in Rise of Nation. They have names, there own look, and you only start off with a handfull so you get to know them very well. Remmeber that the gam is still in alpha, so there will be bugs and lack of content.Good:-City building (I like sandbox city building games)-Can turn enemies on and off-Kid freindly-Nice UI-Can design buildings-If your not gooding at building your own houses, you can use pre-made ones.-Even there it is still alpha, it's not an aboundend Early Access Game like banished and other uncompleted games that are on steam-The devs will sometimes stream them working on the games so they can get live feedback with the fans and can add what the fans want while the fan talks about it.Bad:-It's early access, there are bugs and a lack of content, but they are still coming out with updates to add the contenct. They even have a multiplayer mode planed.-Lack of tutorial so it can be hard for new players, but the games is only in alpha and there most likely will add that later.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth. Not to be confused with the card game Hearthstone nor the novel Stone Heart by Charlie Fletcher.It's a medieval town building game where you control what your settlers, also known as Hearthlings, do, somewhat.It has a Sims-esque overhead view where you can position the camera to watch settlers eat, sleep, mourn over the fact they ate a turnip raw, or plant the camera into a nearby mountain and see how fast you can scroll out of the mountain.Enough about the camera, what about the gameplay?It does have strong points, the Hearthlings can farm, mine, deforest an ecosystem for a chair, or be threatened by goblins about 1/3 of their height. Hearthlings don't fight back when attacked by monsters. Oh, sorry, they do. They just have to have another Hearthling be killed in order to do 1/4 a heart of damage. Sort of a human shield metaphor going on.The only ones who will fight back before wimping out because they were attacked are footmen, knights, archers, and walking bandages- whoops. I meant clerics. I thought this supposed to be a town building game, not a DnD set up.Before I continue, I'd just like to point out that the "heart" I speak of serve as a HP bar, when there is only one heart.The combat is interesting, albeit unforgiving if you are outnumbered. Enemies will group up if Hearthlings don't kill them fast enough and they will chop at their health like a chef to a carrot.Speaking of carrots, there's farming. It is quite smart to have a rot system on raw ingredients, but from what I know, cooking the food will eliminate rotting and make it an MRE, essentially. But before your Hearthlings can have a nice serving of cold soup, you must have a cook because it seems like the Hearthlings were spoonfed and never learned how to roast a carrot over the campfire you are given from the very start. Oh yeah, there are levels for jobs as well, still leaning to the DnD metaphor, since the Hearthlings get buffs and skills from leveling up. Extra damage, more recipes, being able to herd sheep you pulled from your bum."Ok, it looks like I need an archer and a knight since these footmen are getting destroyed by a sentient stump.""Hold on there! Your footmen are only level 2! They need to be level 3 before you can promote them! Just have them walk in circles around that small farm plot for 4 hours!""That seems easy, 4 hours ingame isn't that long, it's 4 minutes.""No, I meant 4 hours in real time."So I may have exaggerated there about leveling up. The Hearthlings level up their job by, er, doing their job. Farmers farm, Blacksmiths smith, Soldiers stare at dirt.Some Hearthlings level up faster than others because of their special buffs. There are 3, but based on value, the only ones worth having are Body and Mind. Body (health) is pretty straight forward. Mind makes your Hearthlings level faster and create better versions of items.I didn't really understand that. How does a carpenter take the materials to make 1 chair and create 2, while one chair is of higher quality?The higher quality furniture doesn't have any other use other than having a nicer look and a higher gold value. Trading in this game is similar to other games; Vender sells item at a fixed price, you can sell the same item for half. Sometimes you can get specialty deals from wandering traders. While some are good, the others are asinine. Some come along the line of "I'll give you one twig for your 54 baskets of pumpkins!" or "I'll give you 40 steel bars if you show me a smile, you heartless being!" Before you can make this transaction, you must wait a period because, I don't know, the trader has to preform a broadway play or something. Which makes sense, they make a deal which can be done in a minute or in 5 days. Sometimes you can get a trade for something from the other band of Hearthlings, which is nice if you hate seeing the same stalks of yellow vegetables. I couldn't say it WORKS yet, let me find out later, I got an offer for watermellon seeds and it just seems like it took my corn.Deforestation is also an issue. They fixed that by adding farmable saplings. "What? Now it's both DnD AND Minecraft?! It's just a rip!" And that is why those who point out things like that shouldn't make reviews. Wait... Anyway, be prepared to either have a sapling farm that makes 1 sapling every harvest, which isn't a lot, or 200 every harvest, which is just a tad too much.While writing this, I realized this review was long. Before I end this and rethink my life, there are a couple of things.Do I recommend it? Yes, I do. I'd recommend it only to people with beefy computers.What did you mean "control the Hearthlings somewhat?" Hearthlings act like they are their own AI, they run to get a log of wood that is guarded heavily by wolves. They destroy ladders from construction of a building while a Hearthling or 2 are still on the roof. Which, in return, they die from lack of food and things to do.What's a good starting point? Stay in the forests and on ledges, you can dig a trench and monsters won't attack your town (it actually does work based on it's pathfinding).

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has more in it than one would expect from an Alpha game. There is such a huge amount of fun to be had during your first play through, if you don't die that is, while unlocking the new jobs you can assign to your citizens. The game is cute and also quite the management simulator making decisions on what products you need vs how fast or what order you should do them in in order to keep your troops geared and healed to keep protecting your town etc. Overall this game is gonna get 4 big stars from me. The only reason I wouldn't give it 5 is tha the combat is just a bit bland. There are the healers, archers, and melee units. There is no differences between healers and archers they all work the same there is just a slight difference in melee units. All melee you will face only damage 1 of your guys at a time and just have a smack battle to see who dies first the only melee that is different are the giant ogres which have an aoe. So the combat is very cool looking and you have a lot of control as to what your individual fights do but the actual mechanic variety in the enemies is low to non but hey its Alpha theres alot of potential to be had.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								When it comes to voxel games this might be the next holy grail. A sandbox "city building" game with crafting support and basic trading, this one mixes it all into one enjoyable game.Due to its early access phase its not a game I would suggest everybody to play right now. However, if you are not easily aggrivated by bugs in an early access game this might be the one game you have to try in the least.This game has a very active community which can be found trough the discourse Stonehearth website.Ofcourse the quality of the game isn't decided by its community, but the support the developers receive of all the players does help it to get in on track of becoming one of the better games out there. What does make the game so great is that it carries a replayability in its core design that will keep the players coming back over and over to sink more hours into Stonehearth.The music you hear while playing is not distracting and fits the game just right. Same goes for most of the sound effects. After about 15 minutes you'll learn to recognise the warning sounds from when your town is under attack and it feels almost like it has always been that way.The graphics aren't the best but its a voxel game that pushes the feeling of older 8-bit games into a modern 3D game environment. And it does it great, it shows a style that wasn't unique among similar games but if you see video's of screenshots you know that its Stonehearth. Together with the sound and music it just fits.The UI is userfriendly enough that without a tutorial you will learn to use it within the first 30 minutes. A small concern is the usage of the combat menu. You will navigate trough to many buttons in my opinion to react quickly enough to the enemy invaders of your town that there is a higher chance that one of your soldiers wont survive the battle.Also, because the game features your villagers as free spirited enitites, you give them commands that arent't always exact. This will give you the feeling that the AI is not listening or your villagers seem to be complete idiots.This can be very frustrating sometimes and with the early access bugs you will need alot of patience.With everything together I would give the game an 8 out of 10 score and when it comes out of early accesss I'd advise it to any voxel/city builder/strategy lover out there to at least give it a try.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Early accessIt's rather fun, and you loose track of time. I easily get bored, fast, and even if I restart "my journey" with these hearthlings over and over (because something in the game didn't work out like I wanted to) I don't get bored - I can restart the game 10 times and it's as fun as the first time, tho it does say something, that I have to restart it 10 times...The good-It's easy to understand how to do things, as there are no instructions or learn-how-to-play-guides in the game. -Fun animations and rather good design. It's like a better version of MInecraft with more characters (several Hearthlings)-It doesn't take time to acheive certain goals you set. There are no goals in game, but if you want to build a huge castle and whatever, it doesn't take forever like in other games.-You don't just like your hearthlings, you love them and care for them.The bad-Remove buildings and other functions doesn't always work, and it seems some of it will never work. Delete a building, sure, but only after you exit and then re-enter the game --- delete or add a specific furniture/object in an existing building, no way José, you better had thought of what you wanted from the beginning!-You don't get to pick your hearthlings - they are diced, and you can't keep the ones you like and dice the rest... Same with map. Everything is random, and maybe that is good, but I like to pick my people and places.-No goals, red thread, main story. It's just  a sandbox... Maybe that's why I keep restarting the game, the biggest challenge is the start-up, after that it's too easy - even in hard mode.The ugly-I have found myself spending more time deciding on what group I shall have and picking the place, when that is done, I exit the game cuz I've been on it for 1,5 hours already...-If things go sour, it's easier to restart than to fix the tragedies... "Oh no, almost everyone died! Meh, I restart it."All in all, the game has room for improvement, but even like it is, it's ok. Minecraft gives me headache, this doesn't.***Added 67 hours into the game***The Ugly -I stand fast about the dicing and rerolls for the pick of hearthlings, yesterday I sat 1 hour just choosing the group. Now THAT gives me headache! Why not a sum of stats that I can hand out?-I have also found out, I have no idea what stats is best for each job. I mean, the herbalist, is that really some physical work or might it need high mental abilities figuring out recipies or is that "I'm one with nature" and need spirit? I understand with the trapper that if I don't want "pets" it should be a hearthling with low spirit, but does that mean that it wont spawn as much critters around?-67 hours in and I still can't figure some stuff out, does curtains buff the mood, what job requires what stats, why does the lake empty as soon as I build a mote?!

								If you quite like sandbox games where you build and mine, this is not the game for you. Early Access Review
								TL;DR= Wait to get it- give it a few more updates or wait until it's on sale, and then try it. It's going to be a super-fun game when it's finished. :)------I really, really want to love this game, and there's SOOOO MUCH POTENTIAL! Especially if they fill in the "talent/job trees" and optimize the graphics a bit."Why I'm downvoting": I'm usually really comfortable with games with lots of bugs in it- I can generally find a run-around and it's not a big deal.However in the case of Stonehearth, several of the bugs are completely game breaking (Not finishing building construction, villagers idling without reason, crafting tables not working (GUI reloads not working), etc..) and due to one reason or another I've found I've had to start a new game every 2-3 hours or so.  Which is frustrating when the game is pretty much all about resource gathering and village progression/development.When it's finished/optimized, I will absolutely re-throw my money at the developers wholeheartedly.

Early Access Review
								Before you play even though the reviews are very positive, make sure there is a sale before spending $25 or so.The game somewhat acts alot like Rimworld and Minecraft except you cant manually control your civilians.Bugs Ive encountered: missing heads, or head is where the torso of the character is, Stop building and working, no tutorial even though it takes around a hour to figure out how things work. For me after and hour of playing, didnt even save the game yet, a UI error appeared and the game broke, it was somewhat playable but i couldnt open my building tabs or job menus.... this was truly a waste of $25... ive read the reviews and watched gameplay... i reccomend you buy this when it is fully developed or when they lower the prive because this is more of a $10 game than it is $25... But hey add some things and it might even be worth $14.99 but not $25, even if everything is fixed and done it wont be worth $25, thats just a ripoff.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you quite like sandbox games where you build and mine, this is not the game for you. I am completely aware that this game is in early access and that content has not all been fixed in place, however there are other games out there that do the same thing, but better and cheaper. The price tag for this game is steep, $25. I managed to play 8 hours, while most of that was just waiting for the little villagers to complete their tasks, and the game was pretty much over. This game is worth $5. If you are looking for an interesting game to play that are similar I would reccommend Gnomoria, Craft The World, and Banished. Totally worth the money. You can get both Gnomoria and Banished for $27. Go that route, I should have listened to Tom.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								When it comes to voxel games this might be the next holy grail. A sandbox "city building" game with crafting support and basic trading, this one mixes it all into one enjoyable game.Due to its early access phase its not a game I would suggest everybody to play right now. However, if you are not easily aggrivated by bugs in an early access game this might be the one game you have to try in the least.This game has a very active community which can be found trough the discourse Stonehearth website.Ofcourse the quality of the game isn't decided by its community, but the support the developers receive of all the players does help it to get in on track of becoming one of the better games out there. What does make the game so great is that it carries a replayability in its core design that will keep the players coming back over and over to sink more hours into Stonehearth.The music you hear while playing is not distracting and fits the game just right. Same goes for most of the sound effects. After about 15 minutes you'll learn to recognise the warning sounds from when your town is under attack and it feels almost like it has always been that way.The graphics aren't the best but its a voxel game that pushes the feeling of older 8-bit games into a modern 3D game environment. And it does it great, it shows a style that wasn't unique among similar games but if you see video's of screenshots you know that its Stonehearth. Together with the sound and music it just fits.The UI is userfriendly enough that without a tutorial you will learn to use it within the first 30 minutes. A small concern is the usage of the combat menu. You will navigate trough to many buttons in my opinion to react quickly enough to the enemy invaders of your town that there is a higher chance that one of your soldiers wont survive the battle.Also, because the game features your villagers as free spirited enitites, you give them commands that arent't always exact. This will give you the feeling that the AI is not listening or your villagers seem to be complete idiots.This can be very frustrating sometimes and with the early access bugs you will need alot of patience.With everything together I would give the game an 8 out of 10 score and when it comes out of early accesss I'd advise it to any voxel/city builder/strategy lover out there to at least give it a try.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								It has the potential to become something great, but i feel the game is a little disorganized in gameplay.  Theres some micromanagement needed to produce goods, and I feel the hearthlings needs better AI to collect reasources and items that are just lying on the ground. Not only that I have trouble crafting because i don't have an instant idea of what reasources i already have and and what i need to craft new items and even build buildings. I guess what I think the game really needs right now is for the hearthlings to become more intilligent and autnomous so that they're always doing something productive other than restocking the stockpile when i'm not giving orders.These are all things i think should be dealt with as the game updates. Quite frankly i'm impressed that the game is set to continue running depsite all the erros and bugs that pop up which is of course a clear indication that the game still needs some polishing. But I am sure that once this game is eventually completed it should become something very fun.

Early Access Review
								One of the backers, here. Game is still in early alpha, but, by this point, has a fair amount to offer. Multiple-story buildings, combat, raids and counter-raids, and some nasties that come say hi at night. Great town simulation game with fun RPG elements.At the moment it's still short of what it wants to be, but with the progress the devs have made in the transparency in their progression, I doubt it will be long before you can play with your buddies and experience the other classes and goodies the game will offer.It's a game I've had fun coming back to nearly every update, and one that I eagerly await release of. Keep up the good work, Radiant!

But in its current state the game is way too expensive.

Once this issue with lag and RAM hogging is resolved it would be a great game and I will recommend the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								TL;DR - If you like sim/survival games à la Gnomoria, Craft the World, etc... This game VERY worth it.This is one of the best Dwarf Fortress clone on the market at the moment. It beats games like Gnomoria out of the water mainly because of slick UI and easy to navigate Z axis for depth mining.There are bugs. But nothing extremely game breaking at the moment, the devs seem to be doing a good job of cleaning up their code.As some people mentioned, VERY CPU intensive. I've noticed that it seems the game has a memory leak problem, it'll run smooth for a few hours, but after 3-4 hours straight in one settlement, it starts to frame lag. Closing the program, waiting, and restarting fixes this. So at least it's not something permanent even if you have 30+ settles and a lot of business on the screen.I love the Tech tree idea, I hope it will come with a lots more jobs and advacements.Building design is HARD! If you're new, don't bother with it, take the default buildings and run with that. After a few games you can start banging your head on the design thing. It's not intuitive, that's the biggest problem, but once you get the functions, it DOES get  quite easy.Pros- FUN! The game might not be feature complete, but it's a hell of a lof of fun- Slick UI and non-confusing X,Y,Z in 3D environment nagivation (not easy to do imho)-Crafting! Gosh I love crafting, and this has already quite a few recipes. Could have a lot more, hope it gets more, but already very satisfactory- Sound and music: bravo- The two different tribes and map types give interesting variation in gameplay. - Some jobs are retro compatible, e.g. cook will keep faming. Which is a very cool feature- There are small quests and bigger mission types to get your town marked with township and such, so keep on going even if it seems you are at the end of progression, some nifty things are coming your way- Nice graphicsCons- Seems the mobs are very scripted, completely not random. Depending on your difficulty, you will always get the same waves at the same time. There are random mobs and spawns on the map, but by now I can already mark down when the first 5-10 invasions will happen in a Mid or Hard game. Takes away from the excitement.- Some bugs. Most annoying at the moment for me is that after level 6 or so while digging, mining highlight do not sticky. The task seems to be set in, but the yellow marker doesn't show. Hard to keep track of where I clicked.- Current soldier AI is not very good. I've had my soldiers die because they completely split up when attacking, specially when chasing Archer/Ranged type enemies, and they end up dying 1 by 1 even at high levels because they just don't work together. Lots of micromanagement needed on your troops which can be annoying.- Some parts of the game are no obvious. Where do you get sheep, or Poyos? Still need to find it out...Suggestions- Give workers levels too. They work so hard, and get nothing for it, poor things. But seriously, it would make sense to have your base workers be able to gain levels and maybe advance in things like: harvesting, mining, hauling (inventory expansions, etc...)- Priority system for the regular worker tasks (see Craft the World)-Allow remapping of the keys! I can't tell you how many times I send my damn tribe in alert mode because I am trying to turn a furniture piece to the left before placement, whoever took R as the alarm instead of ROTATION never played these games before :P- It doesn't seem to have any benefit to level up a class to the max before promoting your Hearthling to the next job. Would be cool if some bonuses would stick. Specially when it comes to the military, as a Knight level 1 might get trampled even if he was a Footman level 6 before.- Would be nice to be able to set patrol areas for your soldiers, instead of having them just marching in the base camp all the time- And on/off switch for soldiers would be great. If not walking/training, they could function as regular workers- Training area for soldiers/archers etc...- MORE MAGIC! Love the cleric, need more- Babies! Marriage, love, interactions, old age?- Fishing!- Multiplayer would be a blast, but I guess quite hard to do with Co-Op mode?- Dyes for clothes, more clothes with bonuses for the various jobs- Bit more functionalities for pets, don't even notice I have any most of the timeSpecsWin 10intel i7 479016 GB RAMGeForce GTX 980

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've had this game for about six months now. Enjoyed it a lot ! This game is brilliant and is kind of  defining a new game "genre" with it's unsual mix. Minecraft, Final Fantasy Tactics, real-time strategy with complex economy and yet... a significant touch of RPG. You really have to try it in order to understand the thin line on which the devs are refining the new concept. One of the best thing is probably it's adaptability. The game let you choose without asking or inteferring if you want to focus on building peacefully or on the adventure and the fighting... or both. You don't have to developp and max every job tree available, yet you can try and face a really interesting challenge.BUT... I'm beginning to be bored. Maybe it's the fact that the game developped so fast during the first months... now the last 2 alphas we're about the building system. But everytime I come back and try and lunch a new game to see if the bugs in the building system got rid of... I just face the same fact : those scaffolding are driving me mad ! It's still impossible to build a decent 10x14 blocs, 2 floors house without having those staying on the stairs inside or on the walls or on the cliffs or...whatever... Are the devs going to clear this bug definitely one day ?

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a rather charming village builder. You start out with a handfull of "Hearthlings" to start out your village. By making buildings, gathering food, getting wealth, and keeping moral you can grow your population. I have been playing this on and off for the past year or so and have seen some great improvements from the devs and can't wait to see what is coming in the future. You kind of have to be in the right mood to play this game; sort of in a relaxed, animated fantasy sort of mood. But I suppose you kind of have to be in the right mood to play any game. Today, I'm going to break the mold and start with cons:-It's still in alpha. There are some bugs yet and I have found some in various parts of the game. -There isn't much of an end game. (That I know of)-the bugs that are fixed cometimes create new bugs. Pros:-The building aspect offers some cusomization with custom floor plan, building material, and a bit on roof design.-Depending on which job you give your Hearthling, they will progress in levels and you can promote them to an advanced job or let them increase their level at the current job and be more productive.-You have hard mode which offers a big challenge to your management with planning and managing. -The devs are very active and take in feedback and bug reports and fix them within a few weeks. -The devs also keep regular updates in blogs every other (or every) Tuesday about what's going on and near future plans. -I enjoy the cartoony art style. The Hearthlings are cute and the monsters are kind of ugly but in a cartoon, funny kind of way. -There is a job tree with various different jobs to give your villagers which is still in progress but improving with every alpha release. Hope this helps.

For some reason they just refuse to make stuff for the longest of times and blacksmiths focus more on building than cfrating what you ordered and so on. Doesnt seem to be other players as of yet even ai is only limited too some random single or up to five unit squads attacking, but no bases or ai players to attack or loot. Very small map too. Still I am going to put this as a positive review because of the potential and what this game could be. Please dear developer, don't screw your fans over. You have asked a high price and received it, please live up to the expectations that come with it.But no updates in a long time and to many bus for me to recommend.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								As a big fan of games like Minecraft and Civilization I decided to buy Stonehearth even though it is only an Alpha. I am very impressed from playing so far (Alpha v11), yes there are bugs which can be game breaking and there is so much more that needs to be added, but this really has the beginnings of a good game. I've done a couple of play throughs and am getting the hang of managing the little town and it is very addictive. At the moment there is a bit of a lack of things to do at the later stages of the game, mining for minerals has only recently been added and beyond upgrading gear doesn't seem to have much purpose, but I'm sure more will be added.Of course, it is still in Alpha so there are many issues that can be annoying, the AI of your workers can be poor at times and they can just get stuck doing nothing. I think it would really benefit this game to allow some control over individual workers, or at least allow some prioritization of tasks because at the moment it is a bit frustrating when for example you want a worker to pick something up that he's stood next to but he just doesn't do it.These bugs aside the game is very promising and I will certainly be following its development closely. If bugs annoy you then I would wait for the retail version. If, like me, you like the look of the game and can't wait, then I don't think you'll be disappointed.

But overall, I'd recommend this even if you don't like Early Access games. This is one that gets better and more interesting with each new build.

content:

Early Access Review
								I got this game months ago, since I wanted something relaxing and sandbox-ish, and this game's charm and city-building/adventure mechanics looked really great. Back then, I had a bit of fun trying to build a village, but found things quickly messed up with buginess, especially with the building editor. Fair enough, I thought. I'll come back to it later.It's been months, and the devs still haven't fixed up the building editor. You can't even undo or delete structures. If you make a mistake, it's permanent. This game has been on the market for almost 3 years, as of writing. Building is a central mechanic. It needs to be playable in this regard before the developers even think about adding other content.Keep an eye on it if this is the kind of game you enjoy, but I'd advise against spending your money on it as of writing.

number of helpful: 12 of 23 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								So far I can gauge this game being a "Minecraft/DF town sim blend done right". Things that are in the game work well and good (until you meet bugs), and the whole process of managing your town is quite smooth and nice, easily the best or near-best of that I've seen in similar games.So, why it's "not recommended"?At the moment, there isn't much to do there. The amount of content that you can try is extremely low, vertical progression is basically nonexistent - you can unlock all the things that are currently implemented in the game in 2 to 3 game days (that's 1-1.5 hours of playtime at most), and afterwards there's nothing left to do apart from "build more stuff because you can and it's the only thing you can".Additonal grain of salt is the building editor - customizable buildings is one of the defining points of the game (that is, one of the defining points that is actually implemented right now), but the editor is rather clunky and hard to use in cases other than traditional 1-story building (multiple stories aren't implemented at the moment) with simple inner structure and minimal amount of walls. Try to do complex multi-room irregurarly-shaped buildings, however, and you will be fighting the UI much more than actually planning.And finally, the pacing of development is nothing to write home about. The initial plans (from Kickstarter campaign) were to release the game towards the end of 2014, you know. Now it's the end of 2015, and we recently had an alpha version where devs were mostly fixing internals, such as pathfinding. Going by this, it is extremely unlikely that we'll see any reasonably-sized chunk of gameplay - that is, content and actual mechanics - available until the end of 2016, and beta/release stages may follow even later. And that's only if the development won't stop abruptly at some point.To summarize, it's a game that promises really great things, but currently allows you to plant turnips, design and build simple small buildings, dig through mountains, and hit randomly-appearing enemies such as goblins with some swords (archery is not implemented yet). That's all.

								This game is fun and over al a great game. Here's a list of the pros and cons. Remember  It is still in alpha Pros: + Fun gameplay+ Easy but still interesting+Awesome artstyle+Over all a great gameCons:-Buggy (remember it is in alpha)-No tutorial (But it is easy to figure out what to do)This is just my opinion, But I also think you should probably watch someone on youtube or something play this, to get a closer feel and to really know what it's like. I could've made a longer list for both the pros and cons, but i just decided to hit the basic points.9/10, Really fun but it's still in alpha and could use a little work.

Early Access Review
								It is fun, I won't deny it. But the vast amount of bugs get in the way of that. From villagers not building things to them getting stuck in walls or tables (sometimes a save and reload just does not work), to not explaining what you can actually do. I designed an amazing house for instance, clicked "build". Nothing. Nothing at all. Nobody doing anything. The worst part is that i still dont know what was the cause. There is nothing to tell me what im doing wrong if I am doing something wrong at all.It is early access and so far the gameplay is fine, but with the large amount of bugs and the high price, I just cant reccomend it in the current condition. But I will be keeping my eye on it.

Early Access Review
								I adore this game.Im a long-time fan of Dwarf Fortress and this immediately appealed to me.  Now, its not as...  baroque as DF, but it shows much potential thus far.  It's regularly updated, has appealing graphics and the custom structure building is pretty great once you get the hang of it.The only con I could see is the price, that and being early-access may not appeal to the more instant-gratification seeking consumer.  It can be a little rough around the edges, but the devs are pretty diligent in stamping out bugs as they come.In conclusion- get it if you want to play a work in progress that already delivers a pretty great experience.  Perhaps wait til its on sale if the price bothers you?

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Current level of recommend?Strong Follow!If your interested in the game I'd give it a follow and check back in a couple months. Game is still very early alpha and most of the updates are focused on making the game more stable while adding in one thing at a time. In its current state for its price, your looking at maybe a weekend or a couple sessions worth of game time. Updates are a bit slow but are pretty steady in frequency. Been playing stonehearth on and off since alpha 5 and the game does have quite a bit of potential (devs are also active on their forums which is a plus)If you do choose to pick it up just remember the early access tag means early access. In its current state you be able to play around with the basics but will likely run into bugs/glitches your village grows. Also, its a good idea to save before you start a new building that way you can reload your save should you run into any bugs/issues.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Hey guys! This is my review of the game as a newbie to it. This Is a honest and non bias review. Ok. So. When first starting out you may be like what the hell but as you start to figure out what there is to do and the system it gets amazingly good! At first I wasn't sure if it was going to be worth $20 (steam summer sale) but within 30 minutes of playing I loved the game. It's fresh, intuitive, creative, and seems to be VERY OPTIMIZED for all of you who don't have the $ for high end pc's. I truly believe this game is worth the money and is definite worth a shot! Especially if your into games that involve build your own community, exploring, surviving, and taking care of your little towns people! The only downside I found to this game was that there was really no clear instructions on how to start or even controls, the controls feel kinda weird but as you progress you start to like them since they make building amazingly easier. Also that the game has a full base building system and resource system, caves digging ext. I am very picky when it comes to these types of games but this one was just to good to let go. Definitely recommend it! Worth your time for sure!!!
